{"Status": "Complete", "Paper Overview": {"type_of_reference": "JOUR", "Title": "Fully stripped? The dynamics of dark and luminous matter in the massive cluster collision MACSJ0553.4-3342", "authors": ["Ebeling, H.", "Qi, J.", "Richard, J."], "author_address": ["AA(Institute for Astronomy, University of Hawaii, 2680 Woodlawn Drive, Honolulu, HI 96822, USA), AB(Institute for Astronomy, University of Hawaii, 2680 Woodlawn Drive, Honolulu, HI 96822, USA), AC(Univ Lyon, Univ Lyon1, Ens de Lyon, CNRS, Centre de Rech\u00e8rche Astrophysique de Lyon UMR5574, F-69230 Saint-Genis-Laval, France)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "471", "publication_year": "2017/11/1", "start_page": "3305", "end_page": "3322", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "galaxies: clusters: individual (MACSJ0553-3342)", "galaxies: clusters: intracluster medium", "galaxies: evolution", "dark matter", "X-rays: galaxies: clusters", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017MNRAS.471.3305E", "abstract": "We present the results of a multiwavelength investigation of the very X-ray luminous galaxy cluster MACSJ0553.4-3342 (z = 0.4270; hereafter MACSJ0553). Combining high-resolution data obtained with the Hubble Space Telescope and the Chandra X-ray Observatory with ground-based galaxy spectroscopy, our analysis establishes the system unambiguously as a binary, post-collision merger of massive clusters. Key characteristics include perfect alignment of luminous and dark matter for one component, a separation of almost 650 kpc (in projection) between the dark-matter peak of the other subcluster and the second X-ray peak, extremely hot gas (kT > 15 keV) at either end of the merger axis, a potential cold front in the east, an unusually low gas mass fraction of approximately 0.075 for the western component, a velocity dispersion of 1490_{-130}^{+104} km s<SUP>-1</SUP>, and no indication of significant substructure along the line of sight. We propose that the MACSJ0553 merger proceeds not in the plane of the sky, but at a large inclination angle, is observed very close to turnaround, and that the eastern X-ray peak is the cool core of the slightly less massive western component that was fully stripped and captured by the eastern subcluster during the collision. If correct, this hypothesis would make MACSJ0553 a superb target for a competitive study of ram-pressure stripping and the collisional behaviour of luminous and dark matter during cluster formation.", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/stx1636", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1706.03535", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "3"}, "ADS link": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017MNRAS.471.3305E", "Publisher link via ADS gateway": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/link_gateway/2017MNRAS.471.3305E/PUB_HTML", "Action": "Scanned and processed all tables", "Paper text": "\r\n\r\n\r\n<!DOCTYPE html>\r\n<html lang=\"en\" class=\"no-js\">\r\n\r\n<head>\r\n\r\n        <title>Fully stripped? </ul>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-nav-dropdown\">\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"navbar\">\r\n    <div class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter at-navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n label=\"Search beyond this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term at-microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=95083807 id=\"95083807\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present the results of a multiwavelength investigation of the very X-ray luminous galaxy cluster MACSJ0553.4\u22123342 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.4270; hereafter MACSJ0553). Combining high-resolution data obtained with the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> and the <em>Chandra</em> X-ray Observatory with ground-based galaxy spectroscopy, our analysis establishes the system unambiguously as a binary, post-collision merger of massive clusters. Key characteristics include perfect alignment of luminous and dark matter for one component, a separation of almost 650\u00a0kpc (in projection) between the dark-matter peak of the other subcluster and the second X-ray peak, extremely hot gas (<em>kT</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a015\u00a0keV) at either end of the merger axis, a potential cold front in the east, an unusually low gas mass fraction of approximately 0.075 for the western component, a velocity dispersion of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1490_{-130}^{+104}$|</span>\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, and no indication of significant substructure along the line of sight. We propose that the MACSJ0553 merger proceeds not in the plane of the sky, but at a large inclination angle, is observed very close to turnaround, and that the eastern X-ray peak is the cool core of the slightly less massive western component that was fully stripped and captured by the eastern subcluster during the collision. If correct, this hypothesis would make MACSJ0553 a superb target for a competitive study of ram-pressure stripping and the collisional behaviour of luminous and dark matter during cluster formation.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: individual (MACSJ0553\u22123342)&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: individual (MACSJ0553\u22123342)</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: intracluster medium&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: intracluster medium</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: evolution&quot;\">galaxies: evolution</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;dark matter&quot;\">dark matter</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;X-rays: galaxies: clusters&quot;\">X-rays: galaxies: clusters</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=95083809 id=\"95083809\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Galaxy clusters, much more so than the galactic \u2018island universes\u2019 of Kant's and Herschel's days, are so large and contain so much matter (both dark and luminous) that they effectively constitute mini universes. Serving as self-contained laboratories, massive clusters allow us to study fundamental properties of a wide range of astrophysical objects. This pertains not only to components of the cluster itself (galaxies, gas and dark matter) but, owing to the magnifying effect of gravitational lensing, also to objects located far behind the cluster (for a review, see Kneib &amp; Natarajan\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). In-depth studies of massive galaxy clusters are critical for both of these aspects: observations of the distribution of all three cluster components probe astrophysical processes at the cluster redshift (such as galaxy transformations, structure formation, properties of dark matter or particle acceleration mechanisms); and the very same observational data also allow us to identify and calibrate these most powerful gravitational lenses for studies of the very distant Universe, as demonstrated by the success of the Hubble Frontier Fields (HFF) project (e.g. Richard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Atek et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Bowler et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Oesch et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Clusters of galaxies that are dynamically disturbed as the result of a recent or ongoing merger are of particular interest. Cluster collisions release an enormous amount of kinetic energy that manifests itself in many forms, including shocks heating the intracluster medium (ICM) and extended radio emission from electrons accelerated to relativistic energies (e.g. Randall et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, and references therein). Offsets between the peaks in the gas, galaxy and dark-matter distribution of merging clusters provide vital clues to the self-interaction cross-section of dark matter (Markevitch et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Clowe et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Brada\u010d et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Harvey et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Last, but not least, merging clusters extend over a larger solid angle on the sky and thus offer significant gravitational amplification to a larger number of background galaxies; it is for this reason that five of the six cluster lenses selected for the HFF are merging systems.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We here describe, and present results from, a joint optical/X-ray study of MACSJ0553.4\u22123342 (MACSJ0553), an X-ray luminous cluster discovered by the Massive Cluster Survey (MACS, Ebeling, Edge &amp; Henry\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Ebeling et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and classified as a likely head-on merger by Mann &amp; Ebeling (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Our paper is organized as follows: having introducing the target of our study in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2</a>, we provide in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a> an overview of the X-ray and optical observations used in our work. We then describe in detail our X-ray analysis in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a> and our approach to constraining the lens model in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>. We present our results in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6</a> and propose a merger scenario that explains all observational evidence in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">7</a>, before summarizing our findings in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec8\"></span><a href=\"#sec8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">8</a> and highlighting future research in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec9\"></span><a href=\"#sec9\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">9</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Throughout this paper we adopt the concordance \u039b cold dark matter cosmology, characterized by \u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.7 and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a070\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>. All images are oriented such that north is up and east is to the left.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=95083814 id=\"95083814\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 MACSJ0553.4\u22123342</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Like all MACS clusters, MACSJ0553 was originally identified as a massive cluster through dedicated optical follow-up imaging of 7\u00a0\u00d7\u00a07\u00a0arcmin<sup>2</sup> regions around X-ray sources detected in the course of the ROSAT All-Sky Survey (RASS, Voges et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Boller et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>); a detailed description of the MACS project can be found in Ebeling et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). Images in the <em>V, R</em> and <em>I</em> bands obtained in 2002 February with the University of Hawai'i\u2019s 2.2m telescope (UH2.2m) on Maunakea unambiguously established the counterpart to the RASS source 1RXS\u00a0J055326.7\u2212334237 as an optically rich galaxy cluster. A preliminary cluster redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.431 was established by long-slit spectroscopy conducted with the Keck-II Echelle Spectrograph and Imager (ESI), leading to a first estimate of the X-ray luminosity of the system of <em>L</em><sub>X</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0(1.63\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.25)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>45</sup>\u00a0erg\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> (0.1\u20132.4\u00a0keV) derived from the 57 photons detected from 1RXS\u00a0J055326.7\u2212334237 in the RASS.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on the galaxy distribution shown in deeper UH2.2m images (taken in 2011 February) and the ICM morphology revealed by a short <em>Chandra</em> X-ray observation of the cluster (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>), Mann &amp; Ebeling (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) classified MACSJ0553 as a likely head-on merger and a promising target for an improved measurement of the dark-matter self-interaction cross-section. Motivated by this assessment, we successfully proposed a joint <em>Chandra</em>/<em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) in-depth study of the system in <em>Chandra</em> Cycle 12 (<em>HST</em> Cycle 18). The observations performed for this project are briefly summarized in the following section.</p>                        <a id=\"95083817\" scrollto-destination=\"95083817\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=y6yJ4ekXgb7Lf~3seEkk3UUIwrHjb9jxooPz8eSlS8IV63XE2nJdBY6U~XtLjilwTP8NngUzWyRSDHuLp~8AktCFDlORlAhKL-dOQlE5vhFkNdWXL4YOPoi5zrjXMQbS~N0T2CuXnB7atpXP~pc8TIHpWfqwZXZqeFTYPRNDRKkPus-3Bz12KukoS731~0rUjK3GS3DcNNU-G~Jy4i4odlyaSmCzyP5SBx0t7c6FW7nH7zmYSjkti4hFYWy55WmpySxl0Mzj6e2EIUP4lmUJpa6jZUEfhBwNcTNEyfyUIcafwOKsio0BstY2MgEwWqQ5nmuj32sbXt06PASTCDOAPA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Iso-intensity contours of the adaptively smoothed X-ray emission from a 10\u00a0ks Chandra observation of MACSJ0553 overlaid on a colour-composite image created from UH2.2m observations conducted in 2011 February in the V, R and I filters. The distribution of both galaxies and intracluster gas is far from regular and relaxed. Reproduced from Mann &amp; Ebeling (2012).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083817/stx1636fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083817\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=0W6WnPKIN17hygj2x1kkoD8Psw8lzNPkeOYUGvwOKufNC-z~I3t9B2vWogQjAjUPX02xy65X-i8mslCsA~I08brP4V7qiIHHFtbUAftE2RZrhk0vkqPygkoxLsIhQM8v2p6tXHbFRSBD4g77XAPtj2cS2A5mz~h40Sj1-YO450AGMc-Klqle5Xv3q-JxP0RN6McKBQmOVVEE5Ixzov0xGlAe8mIwiQMboUgu-CdIHI-a7Z8fA8jBH97qM6Gb7~Sxk0Ett~6pB6Q9mwXGNEFy7fURzfZgG1N4INhH5dpioXyJtuHxc0xXhstsn3Ymbur6qtdes3n3N~C0YS7ZGP50mw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083817&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Iso-intensity contours of the adaptively smoothed X-ray emission from a 10\u00a0ks <em>Chandra</em> observation of MACSJ0553 overlaid on a colour-composite image created from UH2.2m observations conducted in 2011 February in the <em>V, R</em> and <em>I</em> filters. The distribution of both galaxies and intracluster gas is far from regular and relaxed. Reproduced from Mann &amp; Ebeling (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=y6yJ4ekXgb7Lf~3seEkk3UUIwrHjb9jxooPz8eSlS8IV63XE2nJdBY6U~XtLjilwTP8NngUzWyRSDHuLp~8AktCFDlORlAhKL-dOQlE5vhFkNdWXL4YOPoi5zrjXMQbS~N0T2CuXnB7atpXP~pc8TIHpWfqwZXZqeFTYPRNDRKkPus-3Bz12KukoS731~0rUjK3GS3DcNNU-G~Jy4i4odlyaSmCzyP5SBx0t7c6FW7nH7zmYSjkti4hFYWy55WmpySxl0Mzj6e2EIUP4lmUJpa6jZUEfhBwNcTNEyfyUIcafwOKsio0BstY2MgEwWqQ5nmuj32sbXt06PASTCDOAPA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Iso-intensity contours of the adaptively smoothed X-ray emission from a 10\u00a0ks Chandra observation of MACSJ0553 overlaid on a colour-composite image created from UH2.2m observations conducted in 2011 February in the V, R and I filters. The distribution of both galaxies and intracluster gas is far from regular and relaxed. Reproduced from Mann &amp; Ebeling (2012).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083817/stx1636fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083817\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=0W6WnPKIN17hygj2x1kkoD8Psw8lzNPkeOYUGvwOKufNC-z~I3t9B2vWogQjAjUPX02xy65X-i8mslCsA~I08brP4V7qiIHHFtbUAftE2RZrhk0vkqPygkoxLsIhQM8v2p6tXHbFRSBD4g77XAPtj2cS2A5mz~h40Sj1-YO450AGMc-Klqle5Xv3q-JxP0RN6McKBQmOVVEE5Ixzov0xGlAe8mIwiQMboUgu-CdIHI-a7Z8fA8jBH97qM6Gb7~Sxk0Ett~6pB6Q9mwXGNEFy7fURzfZgG1N4INhH5dpioXyJtuHxc0xXhstsn3Ymbur6qtdes3n3N~C0YS7ZGP50mw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083817&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Iso-intensity contours of the adaptively smoothed X-ray emission from a 10\u00a0ks <em>Chandra</em> observation of MACSJ0553 overlaid on a colour-composite image created from UH2.2m observations conducted in 2011 February in the <em>V, R</em> and <em>I</em> filters. The distribution of both galaxies and intracluster gas is far from regular and relaxed. Reproduced from Mann &amp; Ebeling (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=95083818 id=\"95083818\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 OBSERVATIONS AND DATA REDUCTION</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=95083819 id=\"95083819\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Optical</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=95083820 id=\"95083820\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-1>3.1.1 HST imaging</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MACSJ0553 was first observed with the <em>HST</em> in 2008, using the Wide-Field and Planetary Camera 2 (Trauger et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>) for our MACS SNAPshot program GO-11103 (PI: Ebeling). The resulting image in the <em>F</em>606<em>W</em> passband (total exposure time: 1200\u00a0s) is, however, not used by us here, due to the availability of far superior data from subsequent <em>HST</em> observations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observations with <em>HST</em>\u2019s Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS; Ford et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) in the <em>F</em>435<em>W, F</em>606<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> filters were executed for GO-12362 (PI: Ebeling) in 2012 January for total exposure times of 4452, 2092 and 4572\u00a0s, respectively. Additional shallow coverage at near-infrared wavelengths was added through short exposures (656 and 381\u00a0s) with the Wide Field Camera 3 (Kimble et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) in 2016 November for program GO-14096 (PI: Coe) in the <em>F</em>105<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>140<em>W</em> filters. We used the <span class=\"small-caps\">astrodrizzle</span> v2.1.0 software package to remove geometric distortions, background variations and cosmic rays, and to create combined images with a pixel size of 0.03\u00a0arcsec (we set <span class=\"monospace\">pixfrac</span> = 0.7 as recommended by ISR ACS 2015-1). The resulting ACS colour image (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) covers approximately the same area as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and confirms the bimodal nature of the system already apparent in the ground-based image, anchored by two approximately equally luminous brightest cluster galaxies (BCGs), separated by almost 450\u00a0kpc in projection.</p>                        <a id=\"95083823\" scrollto-destination=\"95083823\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=qYxKpLYHR-7FdyraC5NWSzn0i4F3ISyqqkIOzSWE7386XxNx5c4EcL3O8~Gh9e64xz~XFFT46L6naLqLyP~0EwF4JH5eHdShcaNaNrjNMfxCSyqbqwsgWhy8QVmC3-vdClfbB04rJJ2tRNRcLXcwPTjeWTUi5eaHRXcyoWElbiYmBFWEZNSM~RsljQcUWdP545P448AO9g78fSrx1Q62JM7v~h0r7Oh9x1~IqHkHRA6jH~VeVCWRWuXS1tKx9xRBwmdqVwVDWpOAzXExx-L27Yo34WwEc3cGb2RoU6rUqZpnxoDTxrnmSZQNbTJAZxntPChSMPU2KU8tQLpalmcAow__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"MACSJ0553 as seen with HST/ACS (F435W/F606W/F814W). A comparison with Fig.\u00a01 shows that our ACS observation covers essentially all of the area within with X-ray emission was detected with Chandra. Insets (15\u2009arcsec\u00a0\u00d7\u00a015\u2009arcsec) show the brightest cluster galaxies (BCGs); note that the third-brightest galaxy (top left) is a foreground object (see Section\u00a06.1). The projected distance between the BCGs corresponds to 446\u00a0kpc at the cluster redshift. The red circle at the eastern edge of the field marks a binary star used to ensure astrometric alignment with the X-ray data (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>).</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=95083824 id=\"95083824\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-2>3.1.2 Spectroscopy</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">After the redshift of MACSJ0553 was initially established in Keck-II/ESI observations, the system was targeted four more times by us in multi-object spectroscopy observations with the LRIS and DEIMOS spectrographs on Keck-I and -II, respectively (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> for a summary). A slit width of 1\u00a0arcsec was chosen for all observations.</p>                        <a id=\"95083826\" scrollto-destination=\"95083826\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Overview of our spectroscopic observations of MACSJ0553 conducted on Keck-I and -II. When two masks were observed in the same observing run, all slits on strong-lensing features were common to both masks, resulting in exposure times of 4600 and 5700\u00a0s for 2014 November and 2016 October, respectively. The listed seeing is the median-averaged full width at half-maximum of the spatial profile for alignments stars.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Instrument<span 4931\u00a0s\u00a0</td><td>1.5\u00a0arcsec\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DEIMOS\u00a0</td><td>2016 October\u00a0</td><td>Mask 4: 3300\u00a0s\u00a0</td><td>0.9\u00a0arcsec\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>Mask 5: 2400\u00a0s\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0arcsec\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Date<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Exposure time<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Seeing<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>LRIS\u00a0</td><td>2011 December\u00a0</td><td>Blue arm: 3600\u00a0s\u00a0</td><td>1.2\u20131.4\u00a0arcsec\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>Red arm: 3240\u00a0s\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DEIMOS\u00a0</td><td>2014 November\u00a0</td><td>Mask 1: 1600\u00a0s\u00a0</td><td>0.9\u00a0arcsec\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>Mask 2: 3000\u00a0s\u00a0</td><td>0.8\u00a0arcsec\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DEIMOS\u00a0</td><td>2015 November\u00a0</td><td>Mask 3: 4931\u00a0s\u00a0</td><td>1.5\u00a0arcsec\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DEIMOS\u00a0</td><td>2016 October\u00a0</td><td>Mask 4: 3300\u00a0s\u00a0</td><td>0.9\u00a0arcsec\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>Mask 5: 2400\u00a0s\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0arcsec\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/95083826\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">With LRIS, we used the D6800 dichroic to split the incoming light into a blue and red part, directed at the respective arm of the spectrograph. For the red arm, the 600/7500 grating, set to a central wavelength of 8100\u00a0\u00c5, yielded an effective resolution of 5\u00a0\u00c5; on the blue side the 300/5000 grism provided 9\u00a0\u00c5 resolution. With DEIMOS, we used the 600 l\u00a0mm<sup>\u22121</sup> grism and the G455 blocking filter to suppress second-order contamination at wavelengths exceeding 9100\u00a0\u00c5; the effective spectral resolution achieved in these observations is 3.5\u00a0\u00c5.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We used the XIDL and DEEP2 (Cooper et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Newman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) pipelines to reduce the LRIS and DEIMOS data, respectively. Redshifts were measured from the one-dimensional spectra using elements of the <span class=\"small-caps\">specpro</span> software package (Masters &amp; Capak\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=95083829 id=\"95083829\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 X-ray</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MACSJ0553 was observed with the <em>Chandra</em> X-ray Observatory's ACIS-I detector in 2005 (ObsID 5813: PI Ebeling) and again in 2011 (ObsID 12244, PI: Ebeling) for exposure times of 9.9 and 71.9 ks, respectively.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> Both observations were performed in Very Faint mode. We reprocessed the data sets from either observation with the standard <span class=\"small-caps\">ciao</span> analysis tools and Chandra Calibration Database 4.7.2. Periods of flaring background were identified and removed with the help of the <span class=\"monospace\">lc_clean</span> script, before projection of the shorter observation on to the longer one.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> shows the X-ray emission from MACSJ0553 in the <em>Chandra</em> broad-band (0.5\u20137\u00a0keV) after adaptive smoothing of the merged data set. We use <span class=\"small-caps\">asmooth</span> (Ebeling, White &amp; Rangarajan\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) with the default setting of 3\u03c3 for the significance with respect to the local background of any features in the adaptively smoothed image. Note the highly irregular morphology of the X-ray emission and the total absence of an X-ray peak within over 400\u00a0kpc of the BCG of the western subcluster.</p>                        <a id=\"95083832\" scrollto-destination=\"95083832\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=iJz84-rGBaq8gcwPx7-HAlxMa4h8dV0IvpWvYkJ2bkc8F1mhWPQkFpmFELieGLmrKWaa-5VUqZpGgaZ2wolqF9vno4T-ys8Tfiz6TULorT-C4zcJe5FgZvHJmIYRj5Vb2LUnSQUqY3F3~ZIrIiNQ7F96pwUEpjWU3XcTVdB8oJ9-rZ1uUqVTPV-icC8Uz2bk2jFUEmVjXt~0eLRYABGQKXHCxxW74IDXOjgvji9Ca~7WHjiMnonSox4K99z8bVnHtszIYqlcjz2LaSMUJ4VZ5iK6ynBBGi-IbxdNXBYFDVgsmkqadxy9GF6QFcMRm7XdM66D2f1vx~ppO1eovJjuMA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"MACSJ0553 as seen with Chandra/ACIS-I in our merged 82\u2009ks observation; the data were adaptively smoothed to 3\u03c3 significance. The green crosses mark the location of the BCGs highlighted in Fig.\u00a02; r2500 and r1000 are marked by the dashed and solid yellow circle, respectively. The field of view covered by our HST/ACS observation is outlined in cyan, and the ACIS-I chip gaps for ObsIDs 5813 and 12244 are indicated by dashed and solid green lines, respectively. Finally, the inset (15\u2009arcsec\u00a0\u00d7\u00a015\u2009arcsec) shows the perfect alignment between a faint X-ray point source and its optical counterpart, a binary star (cf. The green crosses mark the location of the BCGs highlighted in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>; <em>r</em><sub>2500</sub> and <em>r</em><sub>1000</sub> are marked by the dashed and solid yellow circle, respectively. The green crosses mark the location of the BCGs highlighted in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>; <em>r</em><sub>2500</sub> and <em>r</em><sub>1000</sub> are marked by the dashed and solid yellow circle, respectively. The field of view covered by our <em>HST</em>/ACS observation is outlined in cyan, and the ACIS-I chip gaps for ObsIDs 5813 and 12244 are indicated by dashed and solid green lines, respectively. Finally, the inset (15\u2009arcsec\u00a0\u00d7\u00a015\u2009arcsec) shows the perfect alignment between a faint X-ray point source and its optical counterpart, a binary star (cf. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We take advantage of an X-ray binary within the ACS field of view, detected as a faint point source in our deep ACIS-I observation, to check the consistency of the astrometric solutions of the <em>HST</em> and <em>Chandra</em> observations. We find only a very small offset of 0.44\u00a0arcsec for which we adjust, using the <em>HST</em> astrometry as our reference. For the characterization of the distribution and temperature of the ICM we then mask out all point sources detected by the <span class=\"monospace\">celldetect</span> tool at 3\u03c3 significance. The subsequent analysis of the resulting cleaned X-ray data, including the treatment of background emission, is described in detail in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=95083834 id=\"95083834\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Radio</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MACSJ0553 was observed with the Giant Metrewave Radio Telescope (GMRT) at 323\u00a0GHz by Bonafede et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) who detected a very extended radio halo but no sign of the radio relics they expected from a merger proceeding in the plane of the sky. The GMRT contours are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, overlaid on our X-ray image of MACSJ0553.</p>                        <a id=\"95083836\" scrollto-destination=\"95083836\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=lQgjMS5tnKvRZxT0Q206H5NtHDvWXonVqHyCHdo5fGDrsuLOdeFxhH3yDcfT1hPG9ociej2X3D9l7L04t8cKtY-BqvhPXugT6eCZKl7bOe1oGgIF79zocVgkIGAGiFNG8eqwVYqkOnwNuXj4ZLKsTIFe40G8HaSlRfCm20TyEGve~jWhNP4ejetIr4OUsO09DDDj4SFQwyuBFHi-SNg865ixFlmp0OG-9M866pk7pCn5B6GecQCvVS~zfwUxXZU5OgW9oaiN9704uB7pOKBUD~VQ1gCVKazLlq11prn83X6bkpasuAZRuBJrKOUcmVPyHn8cAj3Ft06VWFZ2SIZ79w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Like Fig.\u00a03, but showing overlaid in magenta the radio contours from GMRT observations at 323\u00a0GHz. Reproduced from Bonafede et\u00a0al. (2012).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083836/stx1636fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083836\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=Q8vIchoG322wzOFJavbeq-GGFxraKi2~4XdcVEge~cmU9DaAZtbtS5F5-yZ74cKcEM3gFkRdhC4jrwiL2FTvSRqBsNOLgozQCHK5FakRvn9tBNsD2sSn3YWOiavxQp5qtCn58OHG7JRcSp4o5Zjw0IMSDDc9HZhdMXfbh5fLzoDsahhLXU0sGLRz-KAiFWT98iqlOVFWgdyJI4opDQGtJQG8JKGK41XNsAxy2cOAZjfKAxN1zivXuHZW-pDEHU5oIhVADK4nj13nUJ48e-kWx1M8OfFvB9oG85HB75JvRah6PSaFWqDH4ly3OtYX5fvkbWHtledFJlaFXiBA~q8cZg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083836&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Like Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, but showing overlaid in magenta the radio contours from GMRT observations at 323\u00a0GHz. Reproduced from Bonafede et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=95083837 id=\"95083837\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 X-RAY ANALYSIS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=95083838 id=\"95083838\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Background subtraction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Background emission recorded in X-ray observations can be divided into two components of different physical origin: photons and high-energy particles. The former component is a combination of unresolved emission from faint sources at high redshift and diffuse emission from gas in our own Galaxy; as such, this component is temporally stable. The latter component, however, which by far dominates the background seen with Chandra's ACIS instrument, is time variable, primarily due to the variability of the Sun's activity.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While it may thus seem advisable to determine the background from the science observation itself by selecting apparently source-free regions of the detector, this strategy has several drawbacks. For one, such designated background regions will, by necessity, fall on to a different part of the detector than the science target and are thus subject to a different instrumental response. Also, the area that can be used to determine the background is restricted to regions well away from the target; if the X-ray emission from the latter is significantly extended, the size of the background region is necessarily reduced. Finally, the accuracy of the background measurement is limited by the statistics set by the duration of the science exposure.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=95083841 id=\"95083841\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-1>4.1.1 Blank-sky background</h4>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">To avoid these complications we here follow the alternative path of determining the X-ray background from separate calibration files, provided by the CALDB for the time of our observation via the <span class=\"monospace\">acis_bkgrnd_lookup</span> tool. As a first step, we project the blank-sky and particle-background<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> data sets thus obtained to the pointing coordinates and orientation of each of our two <em>Chandra</em> observations of MACSJ0553. Following Hickox &amp; Markevitch (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) we then account for the time variability of the particle background by scaling the archival particle background such that it matches our observations in the 9\u201312\u00a0keV range. The required scaling factor is calculated as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nA = \\frac{c({\\rm 9{{\\rm -}}12\\, keV}) - 0.0132 \\times c_{\\rm readout}({\\rm 9{{\\rm -}}12\\, keV})}{c_{\\rm particle}({\\rm 9{{\\rm -}}12\\, keV})},\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where <em>c</em> and <em>c</em><sub>particle</sub> are the count rates in the 9\u201312\u00a0keV range recorded in the photon events files for a given ACIS observation and for the time-matched archival particle-background observation, respectively, while <em>c</em><sub>readout</sub> is the readout contribution to the background, provided by the <span class=\"small-caps\">ciao</span> tool <span class=\"monospace\">readout_bkg</span>. Properly scaled, the particle background <em>A</em>\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0<em>f</em><sub>particle</sub> can then be subtracted across the full spectrum within any given region.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since our analysis works with fluxes, rather than counts, we need to ensure that differences in exposure time as well as the telescope and instrument response are accounted for. We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">ciao</span><span class=\"monospace\">specextract</span> tool to extract spectra from our science data set and to compute the corresponding auxiliary response and redistribution matrix files (ARF and RMF). For the blank-sky and particle-background data sets ARFs and RMFs are not available. We therefore apply the respective ARF and RMF from the science observation to blank-sky and particle-background spectra generated with <span class=\"monospace\">dmextract</span>, and then scale both by appropriate factors to match the exposure time of the science observation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We implement the subtraction of the background by combining two techniques. We directly subtract the appropriately scaled particle background, both from our science observation and the blank-sky data set, within the <span class=\"small-caps\">sherpa</span> environment provided as part of the <span class=\"small-caps\">ciao</span> software package. A different approach is taken for the photon background and described in the following section.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=95083845 id=\"95083845\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-2>4.1.2 Photon background model</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The photon background is not subtracted, but modelled as the sum of thermal emission from the Galactic bubble (Kuntz &amp; Snowden\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; Lumb et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) and a power-law contribution that accounts for unresolved emission from distant AGN. We add a multiplicative exponential term to account for photoelectric absorption by the Galaxy. This model is then fit to the blank-sky data set with all model parameters frozen at their literature values except for their normalizations and the equivalent column density of neutral hydrogen which we set to the value determined from 21\u00a0cm observations in the direction of each target (Kalberla et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>). By fitting both blank-sky data sets simultaneously (one each for ObsIDs 5813 and 12244) and requiring their respective normalizations to match the ratio of the exposure times, we obtain a universal, fully determined model for the photon background that, properly scaled to the area under consideration, can be included in the spectral fits to the data for any region of our science data set. The parameters defining this photon background model are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"95083847\" scrollto-destination=\"95083847\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the components of our model for the photon background as provided by Kuntz &amp; Snowden (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>) and Lumb et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). The only free parameter, <em>N</em>, sets the overall normalization of the photon background; we find <em>N</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.986\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u22124</sup> from a fit to the blank-sky spectra for the I3 CCD of ACIS-I (merged data set).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Component<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"small-caps\">ciao</span> model and parameter values<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Black body I:\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"small-caps\">xsapec</span> (<em>N, kT</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.14\u00a0keV, <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00, <em>Z</em>\u00a0=\u00a0Z<sub>\u2299</sub>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Black body II:\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"small-caps\">xsapec</span> (0.3164\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0<em>N, .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Black body I:\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"small-caps\">xsapec</span> (<em>N, kT</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.14\u00a0keV, <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00, (0.3551\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0<em>N</em>, \u0393\u00a0=\u00a01.42)</span>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). spectra for the I3 CCD of ACIS-I (merged data set).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Component<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"small-caps\">ciao</span> model and parameter values<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Black body I:\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"small-caps\">xsapec</span> (<em>N, kT</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.14\u00a0keV, <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00, .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Black body I:\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"small-caps\">xsapec</span> (<em>N, kT</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.14\u00a0keV, <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00, (0.3551\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0<em>N</em>, \u0393\u00a0=\u00a01.42)</span>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/95083847\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=95083848 id=\"95083848\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Spectral model</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Prior to fitting, spectra from both data sets (ObsIDs 5183 and 12244) are combined using <span class=\"monospace\">specextract</span>; the same procedure is applied to the corresponding particle-background data sets. We then group the spectra, requiring 20 counts per bin, except for fits to the global emission (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.2</a>) where we require 30 counts per bin. After subtraction of the particle-background component we fit a thermal-plasma model for the cluster emission (plus a fixed photon-background contribution) modified by absorption at the observer. In <span class=\"small-caps\">sherpa</span> terms, our model is thus described as <span class=\"monospace\">xswabs</span>\u00d7 (<span class=\"monospace\">xsapec.sc</span>+<span class=\"monospace\">xsapec.bg1</span>+<span class=\"monospace\">xsapec.bg2</span>+<span class=\"monospace\">powlaw1d.bg3</span>), where the final three components describe the photon background (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) and are scaled to the area of the region of interest.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=95083850 id=\"95083850\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Temperature trend maps</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to investigate and quantify spatial variations of the ICM temperature in MACSJ0553, we employ the adaptive-grid algorithm <span class=\"small-caps\">contbin</span> (Sanders\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) to create an irregular tessellation whose cells all share the same, pre-set signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) for the net photon counts as recorded in the <em>Chandra</em> broad-band image (0.5\u20137\u00a0keV) of MACSJ0553. By design, <span class=\"small-caps\">contbin</span> generates a set of regions that provide high-resolution sampling in areas of high X-ray flux, and coarse sampling where the signal is close to the background. Note that the constant-SNR criterion can be met by a large number of different tessellations; the solution returned by <span class=\"small-caps\">contbin</span> is just one of many. This can cause significant systematic effects if the quantity computed within each cell is in fact not correlated with flux \u2013 one example of such an uncorrelated quantity being the ICM temperature. In the following, we briefly describe a method developed by us that effectively bootstraps the uncertainties introduced by the precise choice of a cell's geometric shape and placement within a region of a given SNR.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to sample the distribution of possible tessellations and reduce \u201cgeometric bias\u201d, we compute temperature maps for nine variations of the default <span class=\"small-caps\">contbin</span> tessellation, created by varying <span class=\"monospace\">constrainval</span> (which specifies the upper limit on the ellipticity of any given cell) from 1.2 to 2.0 in steps of 0.1. The resulting array of temperature maps<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup> for an SNR value of 20 is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> (top). We then median-average the pixel values in this stack of nine images to arrive at the map shown in the lower panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> which suppresses the geometric bias present in any given tessellation and enhances robust temperature trends that are common to a plurality of realizations. We stress that the apparently much higher resolution provided by the median image is merely the result of the applied pixel-by-pixel averaging process; in general, none of the apparent cells in the median image comes close to meeting the SNR criterion set by us for the counts in the <em>Chandra</em> broad-band. To avoid misunderstandings, we thus refer to these geometrically randomized images as <em>Temperature Trend Maps</em>.</p>                        <a id=\"95083853\" scrollto-destination=\"95083853\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=Kr87p6~tNXZ3Yc-YovaU4oanpNy~zUiDGRo8GLudHS2dCwlMNxxTgCY7qIy1u7ffyBs28LQgJinrBilgEhn3p4sWcHhW67Irf6W5Y6YvU5ndYxxsWDr65C2srHmGUGTxHYhMt~H8-bq1u9aTT7IKObx92G~xmmcgtF1IxbRVu0pPeGIf2SM99I8J98EZ-gITA~S-C6M7JOUp6rMmm~jtFM7OvDr2~pSs~evZg8Rk3mHj64yF~oHx7a7OTjqJR~Og6ScXqLaqs8VXZ8DGgpyszTPeGuCMGArPUshxd5OpTjafqFoaPtVFYXWL8AFzct7yRhbXbSRieq22fRkf0ZiS6Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top: Temperature maps created with contbin for SNR = 20 and maximal ellipticities of 1.1, 1.2, ..., 1.9 (left to right, and top to bottom); cells touching the edges of our data region, and thus dominated by background emission, have been removed. Bottom: Temperature-trend map for SNR = 20, created by median averaging the pixel values from the nine individual temperature maps shown in the top panel.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083853/stx1636fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083853\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=DlKJwfgBKyUIl3fWfaWkvH3ylWcsaqE-WLdvDcB-5TftBxbcrGAH7dFzizlW~0UJX-fW5Qhgwaf6-YkvtI6bh26bwSdvxpUjtwbYjfCN5ZFAqBC0T4Lw1u-8vHumJ-NKAEyYR98zEdXzyf970E2HS~-mHywLIy-Zg77wcNvLBFC2CfyoRf5cWCJ6r6eIFHyaBv-xAmLG0G6svlFqzxe2x5yQV-ylIeMkx2sWwboUbYLMCEG196-OGGsHIg-RkUfYGy0wtRaGKeCFdEXUr0qFvPpdlvzXD~xQ3fiLcmrDdNU5uqGoIFqw-eLc3kdxx89rutM~y2HwGMJsf~D4Lhg4Gg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083853&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Top: Temperature maps created with <span class=\"small-caps\">contbin</span> for SNR = 20 and maximal ellipticities of 1.1, 1.2, ..., 1.9 (left to right, and top to bottom); cells touching the edges of our data region, and thus dominated by background emission, have been removed. Bottom: Temperature-trend map for SNR = 20, created by median averaging the pixel values from the nine individual temperature maps shown in the top panel.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=Kr87p6~tNXZ3Yc-YovaU4oanpNy~zUiDGRo8GLudHS2dCwlMNxxTgCY7qIy1u7ffyBs28LQgJinrBilgEhn3p4sWcHhW67Irf6W5Y6YvU5ndYxxsWDr65C2srHmGUGTxHYhMt~H8-bq1u9aTT7IKObx92G~xmmcgtF1IxbRVu0pPeGIf2SM99I8J98EZ-gITA~S-C6M7JOUp6rMmm~jtFM7OvDr2~pSs~evZg8Rk3mHj64yF~oHx7a7OTjqJR~Og6ScXqLaqs8VXZ8DGgpyszTPeGuCMGArPUshxd5OpTjafqFoaPtVFYXWL8AFzct7yRhbXbSRieq22fRkf0ZiS6Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top: Temperature maps created with contbin for SNR = 20 and maximal ellipticities of 1.1, 1.2, ..., 1.9 (left to right, and top to bottom); cells touching the edges of our data region, and thus dominated by background emission, have been removed. Bottom: Temperature-trend map for SNR = 20, created by median averaging the pixel values from the nine individual temperature maps shown in the top panel.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083853/stx1636fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083853\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=DlKJwfgBKyUIl3fWfaWkvH3ylWcsaqE-WLdvDcB-5TftBxbcrGAH7dFzizlW~0UJX-fW5Qhgwaf6-YkvtI6bh26bwSdvxpUjtwbYjfCN5ZFAqBC0T4Lw1u-8vHumJ-NKAEyYR98zEdXzyf970E2HS~-mHywLIy-Zg77wcNvLBFC2CfyoRf5cWCJ6r6eIFHyaBv-xAmLG0G6svlFqzxe2x5yQV-ylIeMkx2sWwboUbYLMCEG196-OGGsHIg-RkUfYGy0wtRaGKeCFdEXUr0qFvPpdlvzXD~xQ3fiLcmrDdNU5uqGoIFqw-eLc3kdxx89rutM~y2HwGMJsf~D4Lhg4Gg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083853&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Top: Temperature maps created with <span class=\"small-caps\">contbin</span> for SNR = 20 and maximal ellipticities of 1.1, 1.2, ..., 1.9 (left to right, and top to bottom); cells touching the edges of our data region, and thus dominated by background emission, have been removed. Bottom: Temperature-trend map for SNR = 20, created by median averaging the pixel values from the nine individual temperature maps shown in the top panel.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=95083854 id=\"95083854\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4>4.4 Spatial modelling</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Although the heavily disturbed X-ray morphology of MACSJ0553 (individual features are discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.2.1</a>) and the limited photon statistics of the existing <em>Chandra</em> observations prevent a physically meaningful modelling of the observed surface brightness distribution (let alone any deprojection analysis), we none the less attempt to quantify and compare the large-scale X-ray emission from the ICM of the two apparent cluster components anchored by the system's two BCGs. To this end we bin the X-ray data within a 6.3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a06.3\u00a0arcmin<sup>2</sup> region (approximately 1\u00a0Mpc on the side) into 3\u00a0arcsec pixels, and then remove the irregularly shaped X-ray peak in the far east of the system (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>) by replacing the pixel values in this area with the azimuthal average observed on either side, adopting the western X-ray peak as the centre, and adding noise commensurate with the photon statistics. We subsequently fit two elliptical, two-dimensional \u03b2 models (Cavaliere &amp; Fusco-Femiano\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1976</a>, <span class=\"small-caps\">beta2d</span> in <span class=\"small-caps\">sherpa</span>) to the resulting surface-brightness image, <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\nS(\\hat{r})=S_0 \\left[1+\\left({\\hat{r} \\over r_0}\\right)^2\\right]^{-3\\beta +0.5},\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div></div>where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hat{r}$|</span> is the projected, elliptical radius on the sky, <em>S</em><sub>0</sub> is the central surface brightness, \u03b2 is the power index and <em>r</em><sub>0</sub> is the core radius (see <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://cxc.harvard.edu/sherpa/ahelp/beta2d.html\" target=\"_blank\">http://cxc.harvard.edu/sherpa/ahelp/beta2d.html</a> for details). The gas density is then given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\n\\rho (r)=\\rho _0 \\left[1+\\left({r \\over r_0}\\right)^2\\right]^{-{3\\over 2}\\beta },\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div></div>with <em>r</em> and \u03c1<sub>0</sub> being the three-dimensional radius and the central gas density, respectively. \u03c1<sub>0</sub> is obtained by equating the integral of the emission measure to the normalization of the best-fitting spectral model for the emission within the same spatial region, as described in, e.g. Ho, Ebeling &amp; Richard (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) or David, Jones &amp; Forman (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Although the \u03b2 model usually provides a satisfactory description of the X-ray surface brightness distribution of isothermal, relaxed clusters, its single power-law slope is unable to reproduce the radial steepening of the X-ray emission frequently observed at large radii for non-relaxed systems. In addition, its integral, i.e. the total gas mass, diverges for shallow profiles, i.e. low values of \u03b2. For both of these reasons, an additional, multiplicative term, <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\n\\left[1+\\left({r\\over r_{\\rm s}}\\right)^\\gamma \\right]^{-{\\epsilon \\over \\gamma }}\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div></div>was proposed by Vikhlinin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) to reproduce any steepening in the model's radial dependence at a large radius <em>r</em><sub>s</sub>. While Vikhlinin et\u00a0al. find a value of 3 for \u03b3 (the parameter controlling the width of the transition region between the two power-law slopes) to be a universally acceptable choice, their values for both <em>r</em><sub>s</sub> and \u03b5 vary dramatically between clusters, and neither parameter is constrained within the region where our only modestly deep <em>Chandra</em> observation is able to detect the ICM's diffuse X-ray emission (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>). We explore the resulting systematic errors by computing cumulative gas-mass profiles for two plausible values for each of <em>r</em><sub>s</sub> and \u03b5 (1000 and 1500\u00a0kpc, and 2 and 3, respectively) for both components of our double \u03b2 model.</div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=95083857 id=\"95083857\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 STRONG-LENSING ANALYSIS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In the strong-lensing regime, the gravity-induced deflection of light emitted by a distant background object located near a caustic in the source plane can create multiple images of the object. Since gravitational lensing is achromatic and conserves surface brightness, such multiple images can often be readily identified by their matching colours and morphologies, enabling us to invert the lens equation to derive the mass distribution within the cluster lens (e.g. Mellier, Fort &amp; Kneib\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>; Kneib et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Kneib &amp; Natarajan\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our approach to modelling the mass distribution of MACSJ0553 using such strong-lensing constraints follows the strategy applied successfully before by us, most recently for the calibration of the massive cluster lenses selected for the HFF project (e.g. Richard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Specifically, we use <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> (Jullo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) to optimize a parametric model of the mass distribution of the cluster, built from both cluster-size large-scale haloes and smaller, galaxy-sized perturbers, in order to reproduce the strong-lensing constraints derived from the data. In doing so, we adopt dual pseudoisothermal elliptical mass distributions for the model components (Richard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Limousin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) which are characterized by seven parameters (right ascension and declination of the centre, normalization, core radius, cut-off radius, ellipticity and orientation).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cluster members acting as galaxy-scale perturbers are identified by their colours where spectroscopic redshifts (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.1.2</a>) are not available. We adopt values for the location, ellipticity and orientation as measured by SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> (Bertin &amp; Arnouts\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) from the galaxies\u2019 optical appearance in the ACS/<em>F</em>814<em>W</em> image. All other parameters of galaxy-scale mass components are set based on the assumption of a constant mass-to-light ratio: specifically the central velocity dispersion, core and cut-off radii are scaled according to their luminosity, using the respective values of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _0^*$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm core}^*$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm cut}^*$|</span> for an <em>L</em>* galaxy. Since <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm core}^*$|</span> is small, we follow the approach taken by Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) for a similar strong-lensing analysis of clusters at <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.3 by adopting a fixed value <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm core}^* = 0.15$|</span>\u00a0kpc and optimizing the values of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _0^*$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm cut}^*$|</span> using a Gaussian prior <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _0^*=(158\\pm 27)$|</span> km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> and a flat prior in the range <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$10&lt;r_{\\rm cut}^*&lt;100$|</span>\u00a0kpc, respectively.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=95083861 id=\"95083861\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 Strong-lensing features</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our search for strong-lensing features starts from the most obvious sets of multiple images apparent in the <em>HST</em> colour image of MACSJ0553, the bright arcs highly elongated in the north\u2013south direction (labelled systems 3 and 6 in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). We then iteratively refine the model by adding further constraints imposed by multiple-image systems identified based on colour and morphology as well as redshift information. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows an annotated version of the <em>HST</em>/ACS colour image of MACSJ0553 where we highlight 10 multiple-image families identified in this manner; their location and redshifts (either measured or estimated) are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"95083863\" scrollto-destination=\"95083863\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=YVft4K5U9WxhbX~P9Fu1y9E5mIZwDT7Vbej6iEoSrg704S0hBpLmeNXRrjyuDwNPs~2zADUanVZWB4KFA4s7hf6HfhrqBUpFi5SHKJT5iw1BadcMiU2E7cM4wPeIeBIQNC6viHdlDPQm2pTudYmp5cIqHjEsScfms8rk5lJSto4v20~FHTQKUE7HhHxlwBtnwAKdL~sne8YOkn-24a-1KeLtl9XoBK9lJPVQ~kQiY-rxe19I~RJFI75Z-3bVs6gDZrh7eWyq1OtpThQXl9SSN62Yn0oSFY-vvXhLWtsYsd8yftv-iWZtlsKq-FhmhjxLlXAbf77KNwHfoavHQ2dOFQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"As Fig.\u00a02, but highlighting strong-lensing features. Ten multiple-image systems are marked; insets show a 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a03\u00a0arcsec<sup>2</sup> area around the individual images for each family at a more aggressive stretch. For systems 1 and 3, the reddest multiple-image families, we show postage stamps generated from <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>/<em>F</em>814<em>W</em>/<em>F</em>140<em>W</em> images.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"95083864\" scrollto-destination=\"95083864\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiple-image systems as marked in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. Mpc\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>r</em><sub>2500</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0657\u00a0kpc\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Systemic redshift:\u00a0</td><td>0.4270\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Velocity dispersion:\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1490_{-130}^{+104}$|</span>\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Dynamical mass (<em>r</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>r</em><sub>200</sub>):\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M = 4.2^{+0.9}_{-1.0}\\times 10^{15}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Within <em>r</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>r</em><sub>1000</sub>:\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>X-ray flux (0.5\u20137\u00a0keV):\u00a0</td><td>(4.10\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.05)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u221212</sup>\u00a0erg cm<sup>\u22122</sup>\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>ICM
