As in Fig.\u00a013, the width of each curve reflects the systematic uncertainties of the simplistic double \u03b2 model used to crudely parametrize the observed X-ray surface brightness distribution of MACSJ0553.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig19.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083910/stx1636fig19.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig19.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083910\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig19.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=YaF4~GXonA4dmj6hq9x-axLBLqxT9xgEN1muxQs9U9okxSAw-jxaallA49FOPRML1whTYZl~P1f8t-BnovQwzPQGitxD1BL9gnX0cF5FrttMOwM29mxJ0Tx63KfuvFioB0rimMhlj~7IFcK3sPbpn-8FXvOOW2Fe9FzadRdD1tjzijyNTePWUOO~iTA8fSHMdbOF54B-zguzl97Ct91cNo7T8-bVap0KCKLZ48q5gT8NbZiU8L5ji6zEMwyC79NzB1n950ra80XjAigf1CgxmloZGN439yMSXxlpxWEkhQjoYb~xU04RC4o6cwdTyaRkblmiX5JGCIHcThjQqK~fqw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083910&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig19.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Gas mass fraction of the eastern and western component of MACSJ0553 (red and blue curves, respectively), as derived from the profiles shown in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig18\" data-open=\"fig18\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">18</a>. Shown in green are the cumulative gas fractions for the two components of MACSJ0553. Acknowledging the uncertainties in determining r500 for the two subclusters, we show our results for a range of radii between 600 and 1000\u00a0kpc (see Fig.\u00a019). The solid black and blue lines mark the model (and associated uncertainties) proposed by Dvorkin &amp; Rephaeli (2015) to describe the data. Adapted from Dvorkin &amp; Rephaeli\u00a0(2015).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig20.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083911/stx1636fig20.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig20.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083911\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig20.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=N9LKBLaQqUVpHGFkoSPgmzHOXrYTB0SALW~212zQj-nVsJnhRj6gBpGSnhG0zf4gyXia4J0ocMOOFfr4RpVcGpyLzWqBgGXL5klGrNmi-T7RRR4fKUovEAprr3cR2MF~2ig5s84UyYaC1QKFJXS9uBM~p5hz6Ipz~cEk0sQm-OFdQ4erViL~vRa7QsCxbylf-npOaNip4WPioX4alJWcdsJ58XhUxK6V7xGddMeHn6Jl9NtvBz1njyJpPClrlkXAcUoaMjybE9Xt9TURhNVWRHsfCJOtWk3sDRuvJy1rr5EzzTcoqGq2wH6h-gS1G8I~aNU2KL8cn2v1K~hR3b-ktA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083911&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig20.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Gas mass fractions (at <em>r</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>R</em><sub>500</sub>) as a function of cluster mass. Shown in green are the cumulative gas fractions for the two components of MACSJ0553. Acknowledging the uncertainties in determining <em>r</em><sub>500</sub> for the two subclusters, we show our results for a range of radii between 600 and 1000\u00a0kpc (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig19\" data-open=\"fig19\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">19</a>). Adapted from Dvorkin &amp; Rephaeli\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig20\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 20.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig20.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=diprfOmHJN6YgsxgsBmeuoTZ4bbtBQOpGuGJkcQ~h49aUdj7tgYVnAsE7N11MVdVc4kOdKpHzWTKjsB691addOxRU2HxIk2sjVNfJfp4bkmNm2-lX5CxVez3CMEnH3kSzCdUfXVsbuRC3mt1BbpYeZpVjjWmqkWBpuibYYVcDLD1KZbeq-qjkbsJlVsQsq1oxalCXWjAq5sNlK9ZKvbxRsgGMYVox-tG-NeiIP8mY-zDupvhWOT7ip7y7JI~u6Yijd0~1opubGbBPhxsUhoFKj-QkAg5FWytTagppfEAjA1rPWP-MuRbzYxHYchk2D8K0R2tevmyGHskdWhQTc2tCg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Gas mass fractions (at r\u00a0&lt;\u00a0R500) as a function of cluster mass. Shown in green are the cumulative gas fractions for the two components of MACSJ0553. Acknowledging the uncertainties in determining <em>r</em><sub>500</sub> for the two subclusters, we show our results for a range of radii between 600 and 1000\u00a0kpc (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig19\" data-open=\"fig19\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">19</a>). The solid black and blue lines mark the model (and associated uncertainties) proposed by Dvorkin &amp; Rephaeli (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) to describe the data. Adapted from Dvorkin &amp; Rephaeli\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=95083912 id=\"95083912\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>7 DISCUSSION: MERGER GEOMETRY AND HISTORY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The stark differences between the distribution of dark and luminous matter in MACSJ0553 apparent from Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig17\" data-open=\"fig17\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">17</a>, as well as the presence of two extended, arc-like regions of very hot, presumably shock-heated gas (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a>), represent unambiguous evidence of MACSJ0553 being the result of a massive cluster collision, observed well past pericentre passage. The specifics of our findings, however, pose significant challenges for the interpretation of the geometry and evolution of the merger event.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=95083914 id=\"95083914\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7-1>7.1 X-ray/optical/dark-matter alignments</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We first note the excellent agreement between the locations of the eastern BCG, the eastern mass concentration, and the <em>western</em> X-ray peak. Although this could be the result of a projection effect, such perfect X-ray/optical alignment is more plausibly accounted for by a tight physical association of all three components. Since the high velocities attained in cluster mergers almost invariably lead to a segregation of collisionless and collisional matter (e.g. Clowe et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Brada\u010d et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), we conclude that the eastern component, MACSJ0553-E, must move at negligible speed in the plane of the sky.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Regarding MACSJ0553-W, the western subcluster, we are left with the puzzling scenario of a massive cluster that is devoid of an associated X-ray peak within over 600\u00a0kpc (Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig17\" data-open=\"fig17\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">17</a>). We stress though that MACSJ0553-W is by no means \u2018dark\u2019: it is clearly discernible as a pronounced galaxy overdensity within a radius of 250\u00a0kpc (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>), and the X-ray luminosity within the same radius is 6.7\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>44</sup>\u00a0erg\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> (0.5\u20137\u00a0keV). MACSJ0553-W lacks, however, any semblance of a dense gaseous core, an unprecedented discovery for a system of such enormous mass (<em>M</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a010<sup>15</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>), and indeed features an unusually low gas mass fraction overall (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig20\" data-open=\"fig20\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">20</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Rather than trying to find independent explanations for a massive galaxy cluster without a dense gaseous core in the west of MACSJ0553, and for a dense gaseous core without an associated dark-matter and galaxy overdensity in the east, we propose a scenario that naturally and physically links and explains both of these surprising discoveries. In this scenario, the cool core of the ICM in MACSJ0553-W was completely stripped during the initial collision with the even more massive eastern component, and the eastern X-ray peak (which does not coincide with any galaxy or dark-matter concentration) marks the remnant of this stripped cool core. If our hypothesis is correct (a more extensive discussion is presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec7-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">7.3</a>), the separation of these two components of over 600\u00a0kpc would the largest such offset between dark matter and ICM ever observed in a cluster.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Regarding the X-ray/optical alignment of MACSJ0553-W, the absence of an X-ray peak discussed above prevents us from using any X-ray/optical offset to directly assess the western subcluster's direction of motion and velocity in the plane of the sky. While the latter is somewhat constrained by the good alignment between the location of the BCG and that of a hot region in the ICM temperature map (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a>), we also note the clear (if poorly constrained) southerly offset of about 80\u00a0kpc of the X-ray emission from the western BCG (Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig17\" data-open=\"fig17\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">17</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=95083919 id=\"95083919\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7-2>7.2 Line-of-sight dynamics</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Although the high-velocity dispersion of MACSJ0553 may in part be caused by infall, the unimodal redshift distribution shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> rules out that the two cluster components move at significantly different bulk velocities. Specifically, the redshifts of the BCGs are very similar, their difference amounting to a peculiar velocity of only a few hundred km s<sup>\u22121</sup> (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.1</a>). We conclude that, in addition to featuring negligible velocities in the plane of the sky, both cluster components also move only slowly with respect to each other along the line of sight.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=95083921 id=\"95083921\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7-3>7.3 Merger scenario</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We now consider all observational evidence, as presented in the previous sections of this work, to arrive at a self-consistent scenario for the geometry and temporal evolution of the MACSJ0553 merger event.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Although we find two prominent BCGs in MACSJ0553, two well separated X-ray peaks, and two pronounced dark-matter distributions, the relative positions of these features pose serious challenges for the physical interpretation of the merger history. Considering the absence of X-ray/optical offsets in the eastern cluster core, and the only modest relative line-of-sight velocity of the two subclusters, we propose that the MACSJ0553 merger represents a <em>two-body collision observed near turnaround</em>, i.e. <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\n2r_{\\rm t}sin\\,i={\\rm 450\\,\\,kpc},\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div></div>where <em>r</em><sub>t</sub> is the turnaround radius in the centre-of-mass frame, and <em>i</em> is the inclination of the merger axis relative to our line of sight (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig21\" data-open=\"fig21\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">21</a>). The orientation of the merger axis is, in principle, undetermined; a merger axis in the plane of the sky, however, can effectively be ruled out since the resulting maximal separation of the two components of 450\u00a0kpc would be unphysically small for systems of such high mass (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig21\" data-open=\"fig21\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">21</a>).</div>                        <a id=\"95083924\" scrollto-destination=\"95083924\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig21\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 21.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig21.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=rzvhj8Cj9aEi8-gvpJmQzAqBHfWRHx8l5Q5aC2fGSM8Xo7Pbq8PyJ0BwDMjfj0h36vHt4LVTKgtu53jQInbE7bnO~Q2CzKHGNvhH~U3rMn7ll~SdSf9U2hxC0maW40NGA2-B9bDa~zJaROMSHmEkYi08HOiAfvtX1gCQMFluChUHXNXQE9aZnbQDNS~9cx39U8yoao9y9wgtlOyGdOCrqMAqviyHvPYE83Q6lrydz6rS85ztgNFtEs32NqGuRhO0VgNkjM8ifHd7vZX0700CYGpdHkyJXaVDHT05COardrUe4rXs990aBtJEIe1Svc3klYlTN8nVZ56p0355NM0HUA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Different turnaround scenarios that match the same projected subcluster separation (green dotted lines). Both trajectories (adapted from galaxy-merger tracks by Qi &amp; Barnes, in preparation) are shown in the centre-of-mass frame for collisions assuming a mass ratio of 1:1 but different impact parameters. The light blue dots mark the locations of the two BCGs at the time of our observation of the system.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig21.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083924/stx1636fig21.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig21.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083924\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig21.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=TlHRQQvgJ~0A7uUvclkBRL4raR8LDMWWHMpV-y1tuY8XvAOoSq39pYd8GHWorzCbu1gt8D6Al7AvcgdTHDTQ9f1UDvOio31k-3PwftQoxIls4wUiw-~giikrHxgQgo0QCcZTRhLQdMAbzL5nlMdnQ0WlIArvlcnxfz6ktgpafUj6HFbI~zvRgvUKDdB7D-oSyggSIL8VqMczPOC-n~UejAHM933S5AW4lNjkVgOat9sRAu693VseySF4WFdXDGggM6~BeY5DrlAHqoRbrQtB0KG5TrZcl9RMx9GHW4M5JSH9d2579qKdCFX4PDIt2SwDVFSozZa3ZKaSNJHRZPMIsw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083924&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig21.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Different turnaround scenarios that match the same projected subcluster separation (green dotted lines). Both trajectories (adapted from galaxy-merger tracks by Qi &amp; Barnes, in preparation) are shown in the centre-of-mass frame for collisions assuming a mass ratio of 1:1 but different impact parameters. The light blue dots mark the locations of the two BCGs at the time of our observation of the system.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig21\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 21.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig21.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=rzvhj8Cj9aEi8-gvpJmQzAqBHfWRHx8l5Q5aC2fGSM8Xo7Pbq8PyJ0BwDMjfj0h36vHt4LVTKgtu53jQInbE7bnO~Q2CzKHGNvhH~U3rMn7ll~SdSf9U2hxC0maW40NGA2-B9bDa~zJaROMSHmEkYi08HOiAfvtX1gCQMFluChUHXNXQE9aZnbQDNS~9cx39U8yoao9y9wgtlOyGdOCrqMAqviyHvPYE83Q6lrydz6rS85ztgNFtEs32NqGuRhO0VgNkjM8ifHd7vZX0700CYGpdHkyJXaVDHT05COardrUe4rXs990aBtJEIe1Svc3klYlTN8nVZ56p0355NM0HUA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Different turnaround scenarios that match the same projected subcluster separation (green dotted lines). Both trajectories (adapted from galaxy-merger tracks by Qi &amp; Barnes, in preparation) are shown in the centre-of-mass frame for collisions assuming a mass ratio of 1:1 but different impact parameters. The light blue dots mark the locations of the two BCGs at the time of our observation of the system.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig21.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083924/stx1636fig21.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig21.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083924\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig21.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=TlHRQQvgJ~0A7uUvclkBRL4raR8LDMWWHMpV-y1tuY8XvAOoSq39pYd8GHWorzCbu1gt8D6Al7AvcgdTHDTQ9f1UDvOio31k-3PwftQoxIls4wUiw-~giikrHxgQgo0QCcZTRhLQdMAbzL5nlMdnQ0WlIArvlcnxfz6ktgpafUj6HFbI~zvRgvUKDdB7D-oSyggSIL8VqMczPOC-n~UejAHM933S5AW4lNjkVgOat9sRAu693VseySF4WFdXDGggM6~BeY5DrlAHqoRbrQtB0KG5TrZcl9RMx9GHW4M5JSH9d2579qKdCFX4PDIt2SwDVFSozZa3ZKaSNJHRZPMIsw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083924&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig21.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Different turnaround scenarios that match the same projected subcluster separation (green dotted lines). Both trajectories (adapted from galaxy-merger tracks by Qi &amp; Barnes, in preparation) are shown in the centre-of-mass frame for collisions assuming a mass ratio of 1:1 but different impact parameters. The light blue dots mark the locations of the two BCGs at the time of our observation of the system.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">This scenario does, however, not explain the location of the eastern X-ray peak <em>outside</em> the turnaround radius. We therefore put forward the additional proposition that the initial encounter of the two clusters occurred at a very small impact parameter, and that the eastern X-ray peak marks the current position of the cool core of MACSJ0553-W that was completely stripped in the collision and slowed sufficiently to be captured by MACSJ0553-E (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig22\" data-open=\"fig22\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">22</a>). A schematic trajectory of the captured core, assuming a 1:8 mass ratio for the involved components, is indicated by the dotted line in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig22\" data-open=\"fig22\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">22</a> and scaled to ensure that the remnant of the stripped cool core is viewed at the observed location.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">6</a></sup> Note that, in this scenario, the eastern X-ray peak represents the emission from the stripped core moving along our line of sight and viewed in projection. If we could rotate MACSJ0553 such that its two BCGs fall on top of each other, the stripped core might be similar in appearance to the very extended X-ray tail of a galaxy group undergoing ram-pressure stripping as it falls into A2142, as described by Eckert et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Although of comparable brightness in X-rays, this highly elongated structure would thus feature a three-dimensional gas density that is significantly lower than that of the largely undisturbed ICM core of MACSJ0553-W.</p>                        <a id=\"95083926\" scrollto-destination=\"95083926\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig22\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 22.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig22.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=WKfkfMLm5DgBqYL~BrZTJXdlU7Meyw6x4Jn7pIi8b5wDG0ur9mEHktLo8muM~WvqtLsk3TeDTqvc~pCA2Nyvxz6WHgJAtPeje~ZC0qRuylGSGFYvXv-ceiz3LgXdfrmovsL-Ck9DWBQD8F1f-TCPac7d2NZ1xcThj~-u17jTfjJUBYiOG1GDBovNjAmG9T2A1sMOGKktdYvGPNSvG7yevHae8miaDrQvY7PeB35XpCoa98cUCfBfQNLiVs2x1KFzWVMWE4pLzIOReLP0B6JLLT78iq9xJ6IKxlkz3K6~hIh~GkVrslpmN-kpDYY9yRQGQPfN6rKJ31Pa1Hhr9l~UmA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Schematic sketch of the MACSJ0553 collision in the centre-of-mass frame. The green, dotted lines mark the projected location of three pertinent features, namely the eastern X-ray peak and the two BCGs. The shown trajectories are adapted from Qi &amp; Barnes (in preparation) and assume a mass ratio of 5:3 (solid lines) and 1:8 (dashed line). The areas outlined in magenta around the adaptively smoothed X-ray emission shown at the bottom of this plot mark the regions of extremely hot ICM from our temperature map (15).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig22.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083926/stx1636fig22.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig22.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083926\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig22.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=Pei1jIc5yKR~L36w13Vw4I2lPhSdRQK1lDjWYWOvyu49SN6y7rbUv5cGLD4Exk~E6Ar3wprh0rwonGj3jw0ur-mTDYrYgu6YvkAf-UFeHeYQRGHYdqSDVZDi61XnOJnRhT3tsagIu49Qgg0ncsEefNbUiLa5~YFSSFlFGyD8Rnn7k5mdCWRLrAf8kstoC8oTbAYmjKgDdNMJqshBlTA0AGaSkfU5pX~UxwMFQDIaGjPbRV4XDWdjVxb6SC-J2ajwQXlYMjqjcTKwTdd4yboTsCGHsrUVr1ZEElqRfq37PNSvKyk6dLrG2H-pljrXM~gH8UnEm90mZdyOI~p4ECtMEw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083926&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig22.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Schematic sketch of the MACSJ0553 collision in the centre-of-mass frame. The green, dotted lines mark the projected location of three pertinent features, namely the eastern X-ray peak and the two BCGs. The shown trajectories are adapted from Qi &amp; Barnes (in preparation) and assume a mass ratio of 5:3 (solid lines) and 1:8 (dashed line). The areas outlined in magenta around the adaptively smoothed X-ray emission shown at the bottom of this plot mark the regions of extremely hot ICM from our temperature map (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig22\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 22.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig22.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=WKfkfMLm5DgBqYL~BrZTJXdlU7Meyw6x4Jn7pIi8b5wDG0ur9mEHktLo8muM~WvqtLsk3TeDTqvc~pCA2Nyvxz6WHgJAtPeje~ZC0qRuylGSGFYvXv-ceiz3LgXdfrmovsL-Ck9DWBQD8F1f-TCPac7d2NZ1xcThj~-u17jTfjJUBYiOG1GDBovNjAmG9T2A1sMOGKktdYvGPNSvG7yevHae8miaDrQvY7PeB35XpCoa98cUCfBfQNLiVs2x1KFzWVMWE4pLzIOReLP0B6JLLT78iq9xJ6IKxlkz3K6~hIh~GkVrslpmN-kpDYY9yRQGQPfN6rKJ31Pa1Hhr9l~UmA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Schematic sketch of the MACSJ0553 collision in the centre-of-mass frame. The green, dotted lines mark the projected location of three pertinent features, namely the eastern X-ray peak and the two BCGs. The shown trajectories are adapted from Qi &amp; Barnes (in preparation) and assume a mass ratio of 5:3 (solid lines) and 1:8 (dashed line). The areas outlined in magenta around the adaptively smoothed X-ray emission shown at the bottom of this plot mark the regions of extremely hot ICM from our temperature map (15).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig22.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083926/stx1636fig22.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig22.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083926\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig22.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=Pei1jIc5yKR~L36w13Vw4I2lPhSdRQK1lDjWYWOvyu49SN6y7rbUv5cGLD4Exk~E6Ar3wprh0rwonGj3jw0ur-mTDYrYgu6YvkAf-UFeHeYQRGHYdqSDVZDi61XnOJnRhT3tsagIu49Qgg0ncsEefNbUiLa5~YFSSFlFGyD8Rnn7k5mdCWRLrAf8kstoC8oTbAYmjKgDdNMJqshBlTA0AGaSkfU5pX~UxwMFQDIaGjPbRV4XDWdjVxb6SC-J2ajwQXlYMjqjcTKwTdd4yboTsCGHsrUVr1ZEElqRfq37PNSvKyk6dLrG2H-pljrXM~gH8UnEm90mZdyOI~p4ECtMEw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083926&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig22.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Schematic sketch of the MACSJ0553 collision in the centre-of-mass frame. The green, dotted lines mark the projected location of three pertinent features, namely the eastern X-ray peak and the two BCGs. The shown trajectories are adapted from Qi &amp; Barnes (in preparation) and assume a mass ratio of 5:3 (solid lines) and 1:8 (dashed line). The areas outlined in magenta around the adaptively smoothed X-ray emission shown at the bottom of this plot mark the regions of extremely hot ICM from our temperature map (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our model explains the hot regions in the temperature map (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a>) as follows. Since the peculiar velocities of both MACSJ0553-E and MACSJ0553-W are currently small, no pronounced shock fronts are observed. Shock heating did occur, however, where either cluster component moved at high speed, i.e. primarily close to pericentre passage (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig22\" data-open=\"fig22\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">22</a>). The resulting hot gas has not only had several 100\u00a0Myr to cool and expand; it is also projected on the cooler gas behind and in front of the shocks, thus explaining the lower ICM temperatures measured by us in the central ellipse surrounding the core of MACSJ0553-E. A less obscured view of the shock-heated gas is possible only where it has travelled to larger cluster-centric distances perpendicular to the line of sight, giving rise to the faint but extremely hot ICM observed in the east and west (regions 6 and 8 in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a>). Although a merger of two components of almost equal mass would normally lead to a roughly symmetric appearance of the eastern and western expanding shells, MACSJ0553-W leaves a much broader imprint, owing to the loss of its compact core in the encounter with MACSJ0553-E.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The proposed collision geometry and history finds additional support in the tentative detection of a cold front to the east of what we interpret to be the stripped cool core of MACSJ0553-E (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>). Cold fronts are frequently encountered in mergers and created readily during ram-pressure stripping during pericentre passage, consistent with the results of numerical simulations (e.g. Ascasibar &amp; Markevitch\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). We note, however, that cold fronts are subject to Rayleigh\u2013Taylor instability and require either strong gravitational or magnetic support to remain stable (Markevitch &amp; Vikhlinin\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). The lack of any evidence of a dark-matter concentration at the location of the potential stripped cool core thus represents a significant challenge to the cold-front hypothesis. Part of the hot gas observed along the eastern edge of MACSJ0553 may have been heated by a bow shock that precedes the putative cold front but which, because of the steep inclination of the cool core's velocity vector relative to the plane of the sky, does not manifest itself in a second visible surface brightness discontinuity like the one observed in 1E 0657\u221256 (Markevitch et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>). Although cool cores feature the highest gas densities within the ICM and are thus usually more resilient to ram-pressure stripping than the surrounding, more diffuse gas, full stripping of a cool core has been observed in A520 (Wang, Markevitch &amp; Giacintucci\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), albeit on much more modest scales. As for the remainder of the ICM of MACSJ0553-W, we stress that the available data (in particular the difference in the gas mass fraction between the two cluster components; Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig20\" data-open=\"fig20\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">20</a>) are consistent with gas loss, but do not allow us to assess how much gas was stripped at pericentre passage; part of the gas that gives rise to the diffuse X-ray emission observed today in the western part of the system may in fact have been (re-)accreted and gravitationally heated after the collision.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our scenario is consistent also with the diffuse radio emission from MACSJ0553 as mapped by Bonafede et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. Although radio relics would indeed be expected in the vicinity of the shock fronts, the steep inclination of the merger axis that is a key premise of our merger scenario will cause them to be projected on to the central radio halo. Polarization measurements that allow halo and relic emission to be disentangled could test this prediction (Bonafede et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=95083930 id=\"95083930\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec8>8 SUMMARY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We present a joint X-ray/optical investigation of the extreme cluster merger MACSJ0553 that supersedes the analysis by Harvey et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, see Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec11\"></span><a href=\"#sec11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">B</a>). Our strong-lensing reconstruction of the mass distribution unambiguously detects two components, both featuring a very high mass of <em>M</em>(<em>r</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>r</em><sub>1000</sub>)\u00a0\u223c\u00a03\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> and \u223c6\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> at a separation consistent with that of the two BCGs of the system of 450\u00a0kpc. Moderately deep <em>Chandra</em> observations detect no X-ray core within 450\u00a0kpc of the western component, but two X-ray peaks in the east, one of them perfectly aligned with the BCG of the eastern subcluster. Our analysis of ICM temperature variations finds two arc-shaped regions of hot gas (<em>kT</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a020\u00a0keV) at the eastern and western edge of the X-ray emission, as well as evidence of cooler gas (<em>kT</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a08\u00a0keV) at the location of either X-ray peak. Moreover, the eastern region of very hot gas is preceded by a surface-brightness discontinuity that we tentatively identify as a possible cold front. Ground-based spectroscopy of cluster members yields a global velocity dispersion of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma = 1490_{-130}^{+104}$|</span>\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> and no evidence of velocity substructure along the line of sight.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We attempt to explain all observational evidence by proposing a merger scenario in which MACSJ0553 represents a two-body collision (mass ratio \u223c5:3) at small impact parameter, observed at turnaround. Contrary to the earlier assessment of Mann &amp; Ebeling (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and supporting the suggestion made by Bonafede et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) based on their analysis of MACSJ0553\u2019s radio properties, the merger axis does not lie in the plane of the sky but in fact close to the line of sight.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We account for the total absence of an X-ray luminous core in the western component by postulating that said core was stripped and captured by the eastern subcluster. Moving at high speed through the inner regions of the eastern cluster, the remnant of this stripped core generates a bow shock and a (potential) cold front seen by us in projection. On larger scales, and again viewed mostly in projection, gas that was shock-heated in the primary collision has expanded to create the arc-shaped regions of extremely hot ICM at both the eastern and western end of the system. The hot gas observed at the far western end is more diffuse, reflecting the profile of the core-less western cluster on its path to turnaround. The ICM of the western component is being gravitationally reheated as it is (re-)accreted by the unperturbed deep dark-matter potential around the western BCG.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=95083934 id=\"95083934\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec9>9 THE FUTURE: CHALLENGES AND OPPORTUNITIES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">If our interpretation is correct at least regarding the fundamentals of the merger geometry, MACSJ0553 presents a rare opportunity to determine reliably the three-dimensional trajectories within a massive cluster merger and hence explore several key science questions, due to a number of fortuitous circumstances: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">MACSJ0553 is a binary merger, resulting in a single collision plane that renders this target free of the dynamic complexity of multibody mergers like A520 and A2744 whose three-dimensional merger histories remain almost impenetrable even with extremely deep observations (Merten et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Wang et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>);</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The observation of the merger at turnaround and at an orientation that brings the merger axis close to our line of sight permits a precise measurement of the components\u2019 peculiar velocity.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Testing our theory regarding the fate of the cool core of the (at present) western subcluster is bound to yield additional insights: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The proposed stripping and subsequent capture of the gaseous core of one component by the other requires a very small impact parameter and hence an almost head-on encounter of the densest region of two massive dark-matter haloes. Accurate models of the first core passage of MACSJ0553 would thus not only constrain the collisional and conductive behaviour of hot and cool gas in two massive clusters but also the mass profile in their very core.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Although the proposed merger scenario explains much of the observational evidence, it also faces significant challenges. For one, due to the viscous nature of the ICM, any binary cluster collision should result in a gas distribution that peaks between the BCGs (and dark-matter centroids) of the two components, regardless of orientation to our line of sight. We have attempted to explain the violation of this cardinal rule in MACSJ0553 as the consequence of the effective capture of part of one cluster's ICM by the other; however, much better observational data as well as dedicated hydrodynamical simulations of the MACSJ0553 collision will be needed to test the plausibility of the scenario proposed by us here. Both of these (in particular much deeper X-ray observations) will also be critical to solve the puzzle of the survival of the apparent cold front (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.2.1</a> and Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>) in the absence of gravitational support from an associated dark-matter concentration.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we note that, if improved observational constraints (from additional spectroscopy of both cluster galaxies and multiple-image systems, as well as deeper X-ray and radio observations) combined with numerical simulations of the collision confirm the scenario schematically outlined in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig22\" data-open=\"fig22\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">22</a>, the very high central surface mass densities of the two clusters of nearly 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> and the enormous separation of over 600\u00a0kpc of the gaseous core of MACSJ0553-W from its galaxy population and dark-matter halo could result in an upper limit to \u03c3/<em>m</em> well below 1\u00a0cm<sup>2</sup>\u00a0g<sup>\u22121</sup>, i.e. a value that would be competitive with the constraints set by the Bullet Cluster (Randall et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=95083939 id=\"95083939\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title js-splitscreen-backacknowledgements-title\" >Acknowledgements</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank an anonymous referee whose insightful comments greatly improved this paper, to the extent that a co-authorship would be warranted. Support for program GO-12362 was provided by NASA through a grant from the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS 5-26555. Support for this work was also provided by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration through <em>Chandra</em> Award Number GO1-12153X issued by the Chandra X-ray Observatory Center, which is operated by the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory for and on behalf of the National Aeronautics Space Administration under contract NAS8-03060. JR acknowledges support from ERC starting grant 336736-CALENDS.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Data presented herein were obtained at the W.M. Keck Observatory, which is operated as a scientific partnership among the California Institute of Technology, the University of California, and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The observatory was made possible by the generous finical support of the W.M. Keck Foundation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em>, obtained at the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS 5-26555. These observations are associated with programs GO-12362 and GO-14096.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The authors wish to recognize and acknowledge the very significant cultural role and reverence that the summit of Mauna Kea has always had within the indigenous Hawaiian community. We are most fortunate to have the opportunity to conduct observations from this mountain.</p><div content-id=\"fn1\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">We quote the exposure times of either observation after filtering out periods of high background (flares).</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">These observations were performed with ACIS stowed inside the detector housing and thus do not contain any photon events; by contrast, the very deep blank-sky observations contain both photon and particle background.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">We remove tiles that touch the edge of our data region in order to mitigate the impact of areas dominated by background.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn4\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn4\" class=\"end-note-link\">4</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">We adopt a value \u03c3<sub>pos</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.5\u2009arcsec for the systematic uncertainty in the position of each image.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn5\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn5\" class=\"end-note-link\">5</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Since <em>r</em><sub>1000</sub> is computed from the global cluster gas temperature (Arnaud, Aghanim &amp; Neumann\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>), this is an iterative process.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn6\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn6\" class=\"end-note-link\">6</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The real trajectory is bound to be more complicated but accessible to dynamical modelling of what is now a constrained three-body system.</p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=95083951 id=\"95083951\" class=\"backreferences-title js-splitscreen-backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list js-splitview-ref-list\"><div content-id=\"bib1\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib1\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib1\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Allen</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">S. js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/95083955\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=95083956 id=\"95083956\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec11>APPENDIX B: Analysis by Harvey et\u00a0al.</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">A study aimed at mapping the distribution of gas, galaxies and dark matter in this system was undertaken before. Harvey et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) used the same data for MACSJ0553 (from <em>HST</em> and <em>Chandra</em>) to measure offsets between dark and luminous matter, the former being probed through a weak-lensing analysis of the <em>HST</em> imaging data. Their findings, summarized in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figb1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figb1\" data-open=\"figb1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a>, stand in stark conflict with ours, as their weak-lensing mass reconstruction fails to detect either of the two main mass concentrations in MACSJ0553, and the easternmost peak in their cluster light distribution is based on the erroneous inclusion of the foreground galaxy macsg-J055328.5\u2212334225 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.266; see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a> and Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"95083958\" scrollto-destination=\"95083958\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figb1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636figb1.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=d24DGGZI5qSsu5RcYjG-QPtXrrZhP-XmPtRKtieYJ3lOi-fyoG4ylKfP4au2vM~cMyPSI50A2VuSU~rYCoUGXmDy4567gunr3F6rmr7rmEzRKszy87dC26JsrelX5pIhpKyGDnTON72MjklmV7BZyP6~gceYYeqUR0ooR833OZXCg3tnT8kPkD0Yj~3youi~xgXs3oNYwp0MRLsA5u0xDD3EiiSjoe7I7H6PPdL6A4YfOd0TeVpGMoflW3WO~sr2s7JRibGfQdvZ0jA8KhYB-VcSrrat0r9r6gQaL7tnvcAdVVwP5JuTNgh8FBD4~uIMCW-d2ioXhdqK4SlIDUlF2A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Summary of the findings of Harvey et\u00a0al. (2015) regarding the distribution of dark and luminous matter in MACSJ0553. Blue contours represent the mass distribution as reconstructed from a weak-lensing analysis; red contours represent the X-ray surface brightness; green contours describe the galaxy light distribution. The data underlying their work are the same as the ones used by us here. Reproduced from Harvey et\u00a0al.\u00a0(2015).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636figb1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083958/stx1636figb1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636figb1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083958\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636figb1.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=NOy4DyuDiuHsrnHbY3uJRae8Ozw2JDB0h6LCaDXp0pGgYCl6DqSshTWgctTIhXdRnXAtRm5CsBUCPTWVtY4-dLU0YsSX~lQNaMWKu7J31jOpNzFnPRJA9W~Oh6gXPrajHClFRGseF6Bp-SYctvITwFa6XL6tueriMHjG6hOsZU9ZZe80DDMj26-97RWeLKxV38-L5wavzqn26khx9y3t4EX8ASIXQSCgHDk6zh4dd6wPrKxZ88JhLQEnm05U7ktrg3wA4IQEEF2HBJSjGUTzbeTZoqboAOrnfSFKIXdSWVBezsVD9psweLdrxxKcCsJya4E2-~qyUArRLPMyAaXf-A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083958&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636figb1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the findings of Harvey et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) regarding the distribution of dark and luminous matter in MACSJ0553. Blue contours represent the mass distribution as reconstructed from a weak-lensing analysis; red contours represent the X-ray surface brightness; green contours describe the galaxy light distribution. The data underlying their work are the same as the ones used by us here. Reproduced from Harvey et\u00a0al.\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figb1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636figb1.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=d24DGGZI5qSsu5RcYjG-QPtXrrZhP-XmPtRKtieYJ3lOi-fyoG4ylKfP4au2vM~cMyPSI50A2VuSU~rYCoUGXmDy4567gunr3F6rmr7rmEzRKszy87dC26JsrelX5pIhpKyGDnTON72MjklmV7BZyP6~gceYYeqUR0ooR833OZXCg3tnT8kPkD0Yj~3youi~xgXs3oNYwp0MRLsA5u0xDD3EiiSjoe7I7H6PPdL6A4YfOd0TeVpGMoflW3WO~sr2s7JRibGfQdvZ0jA8KhYB-VcSrrat0r9r6gQaL7tnvcAdVVwP5JuTNgh8FBD4~uIMCW-d2ioXhdqK4SlIDUlF2A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Summary of the findings of Harvey et\u00a0al. (2015) regarding the distribution of dark and luminous matter in MACSJ0553. Blue contours represent the mass distribution as reconstructed from a weak-lensing analysis; red contours represent the X-ray surface brightness; green contours describe the galaxy light distribution. The data underlying their work are the same as the ones used by us here. Reproduced from Harvey et\u00a0al.\u00a0(2015).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636figb1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083958/stx1636figb1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636figb1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083958\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636figb1.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=NOy4DyuDiuHsrnHbY3uJRae8Ozw2JDB0h6LCaDXp0pGgYCl6DqSshTWgctTIhXdRnXAtRm5CsBUCPTWVtY4-dLU0YsSX~lQNaMWKu7J31jOpNzFnPRJA9W~Oh6gXPrajHClFRGseF6Bp-SYctvITwFa6XL6tueriMHjG6hOsZU9ZZe80DDMj26-97RWeLKxV38-L5wavzqn26khx9y3t4EX8ASIXQSCgHDk6zh4dd6wPrKxZ88JhLQEnm05U7ktrg3wA4IQEEF2HBJSjGUTzbeTZoqboAOrnfSFKIXdSWVBezsVD9psweLdrxxKcCsJya4E2-~qyUArRLPMyAaXf-A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083958&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636figb1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the findings of Harvey et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) regarding the distribution of dark and luminous matter in MACSJ0553. Blue contours represent the mass distribution as reconstructed from a weak-lensing analysis; red contours represent the X-ray surface brightness; green contours describe the galaxy light distribution. The data underlying their work are the same as the ones used by us here. Reproduced from Harvey et\u00a0al.\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The distribution of dark and luminous matter in MACSJ0553 derived from our analysis thus supersedes the respective results of Harvey and co-workers, which have been called into question also for other clusters in their sample (Wittman, Golovich &amp; Dawson\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p>        <!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-metadata-standalone-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n\r\n        \r\n<div class=\"copyright copyright-statement\">\u00a9 2017 The Authors Published by Oxford University Press on behalf of the Royal Astronomical Society</div><!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n        <span id=\"UserHasAccess\" data-userHasAccess=\"True\"></span>\r\n\r\n    </div><!-- /.widget-items -->\r\n</div><!--       hfSiteUrl.value = location.host + (subdomainIndex >= 0 ? siteUrl.substring(subdomainIndex) : '');\r\n        })();\r\n    </script>\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" function () {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \r\n    </div>\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleLinks widget-instance-OUP_Article_Links_Widget\">\r\n         \r\n class=\"modal-title\">Cite</h3>\r\n        <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>H. Ebeling, J. Qi, J. Richard,  Fully stripped? The dynamics of dark and luminous matter in the massive cluster collision MACSJ0553.4\u22123342, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 471, Issue 3, November 2017, Pages 3305\u20133322, <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stx1636\">https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stx1636</a></p>\r\n        </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"citation-download-wrap\">\r\n        <form </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=95083807 id=\"95083807\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present the results of a multiwavelength investigation of the very X-ray luminous galaxy cluster MACSJ0553.4\u22123342 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.4270; hereafter MACSJ0553). Combining high-resolution data obtained with the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> and the <em>Chandra</em> X-ray Observatory with ground-based galaxy spectroscopy, our analysis establishes the system unambiguously as a binary, post-collision merger of massive clusters. Key characteristics include perfect alignment of luminous and dark matter for one component, a separation of almost 650\u00a0kpc (in projection) between the dark-matter peak of the other subcluster and the second X-ray peak, extremely hot gas (<em>kT</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a015\u00a0keV) at either end of the merger axis, a potential cold front in the east, an unusually low gas mass fraction of approximately 0.075 for the western component, a velocity dispersion of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1490_{-130}^{+104}$|</span>\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, and no indication of significant substructure along the line of sight. We propose that the MACSJ0553 merger proceeds not in the plane of the sky, but at a large inclination angle, is observed very close to turnaround, and that the eastern X-ray peak is the cool core of the slightly less massive western component that was fully stripped and captured by the eastern subcluster during the collision. If correct, this hypothesis would make MACSJ0553 a superb target for a competitive study of ram-pressure stripping and the collisional behaviour of luminous and dark matter during cluster formation.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: individual (MACSJ0553\u22123342)&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: individual (MACSJ0553\u22123342)</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: intracluster medium&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: intracluster medium</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: evolution&quot;\">galaxies: evolution</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;dark matter&quot;\">dark matter</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;X-rays: galaxies: clusters&quot;\">X-rays: galaxies: clusters</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=95083809 id=\"95083809\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Galaxy clusters, much more so than the galactic \u2018island universes\u2019 of Kant's and Herschel's days, are so large and contain so much matter (both dark and luminous) that they effectively constitute mini universes. Serving as self-contained laboratories, massive clusters allow us to study fundamental properties of a wide range of astrophysical objects. This pertains not only to components of the cluster itself (galaxies, gas and dark matter) but, owing to the magnifying effect of gravitational lensing, also to objects located far behind the cluster (for a review, see Kneib &amp; Natarajan\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). In-depth studies of massive galaxy clusters are critical for both of these aspects: observations of the distribution of all three cluster components probe astrophysical processes at the cluster redshift (such as galaxy transformations, structure formation, properties of dark matter or particle acceleration mechanisms); and the very same observational data also allow us to identify and calibrate these most powerful gravitational lenses for studies of the very distant Universe, as demonstrated by the success of the Hubble Frontier Fields (HFF) project (e.g. Richard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Atek et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Bowler et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Oesch et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Clusters of galaxies that are dynamically disturbed as the result of a recent or ongoing merger are of particular interest. Cluster collisions release an enormous amount of kinetic energy that manifests itself in many forms, including shocks heating the intracluster medium (ICM) and extended radio emission from electrons accelerated to relativistic energies (e.g. Randall et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, and references therein). Offsets between the peaks in the gas, galaxy and dark-matter distribution of merging clusters provide vital clues to the self-interaction cross-section of dark matter (Markevitch et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Clowe et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Brada\u010d et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Harvey et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Last, but not least, merging clusters extend over a larger solid angle on the sky and thus offer significant gravitational amplification to a larger number of background galaxies; it is for this reason that five of the six cluster lenses selected for the HFF are merging systems.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We here describe, and present results from, a joint optical/X-ray study of MACSJ0553.4\u22123342 (MACSJ0553), an X-ray luminous cluster discovered by the Massive Cluster Survey (MACS, Ebeling, Edge &amp; Henry\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Ebeling et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and classified as a likely head-on merger by Mann &amp; Ebeling (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Our paper is organized as follows: having introducing the target of our study in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2</a>, we provide in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a> an overview of the X-ray and optical observations used in our work. We then describe in detail our X-ray analysis in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a> and our approach to constraining the lens model in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>. We present our results in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6</a> and propose a merger scenario that explains all observational evidence in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">7</a>, before summarizing our findings in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec8\"></span><a href=\"#sec8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">8</a> and highlighting future research in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec9\"></span><a href=\"#sec9\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">9</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Throughout this paper we adopt the concordance \u039b cold dark matter cosmology, characterized by \u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.7 and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a070\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>. All images are oriented such that north is up and east is to the left.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=95083814 id=\"95083814\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 MACSJ0553.4\u22123342</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Like all MACS clusters, MACSJ0553 was originally identified as a massive cluster through dedicated optical follow-up imaging of 7\u00a0\u00d7\u00a07\u00a0arcmin<sup>2</sup> regions around X-ray sources detected in the course of the ROSAT All-Sky Survey (RASS, Voges et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Boller et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>); a detailed description of the MACS project can be found in Ebeling et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). Images in the <em>V, R</em> and <em>I</em> bands obtained in 2002 February with the University of Hawai'i\u2019s 2.2m telescope (UH2.2m) on Maunakea unambiguously established the counterpart to the RASS source 1RXS\u00a0J055326.7\u2212334237 as an optically rich galaxy cluster. A preliminary cluster redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.431 was established by long-slit spectroscopy conducted with the Keck-II Echelle Spectrograph and Imager (ESI), leading to a first estimate of the X-ray luminosity of the system of <em>L</em><sub>X</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0(1.63\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.25)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>45</sup>\u00a0erg\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> (0.1\u20132.4\u00a0keV) derived from the 57 photons detected from 1RXS\u00a0J055326.7\u2212334237 in the RASS.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on the galaxy distribution shown in deeper UH2.2m images (taken in 2011 February) and the ICM morphology revealed by a short <em>Chandra</em> X-ray observation of the cluster (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>), Mann &amp; Ebeling (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) classified MACSJ0553 as a likely head-on merger and a promising target for an improved measurement of the dark-matter self-interaction cross-section. Motivated by this assessment, we successfully proposed a joint <em>Chandra</em>/<em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) in-depth study of the system in <em>Chandra</em> Cycle 12 (<em>HST</em> Cycle 18). The observations performed for this project are briefly summarized in the following section.</p>                        <a id=\"95083817\" scrollto-destination=\"95083817\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=y6yJ4ekXgb7Lf~3seEkk3UUIwrHjb9jxooPz8eSlS8IV63XE2nJdBY6U~XtLjilwTP8NngUzWyRSDHuLp~8AktCFDlORlAhKL-dOQlE5vhFkNdWXL4YOPoi5zrjXMQbS~N0T2CuXnB7atpXP~pc8TIHpWfqwZXZqeFTYPRNDRKkPus-3Bz12KukoS731~0rUjK3GS3DcNNU-G~Jy4i4odlyaSmCzyP5SBx0t7c6FW7nH7zmYSjkti4hFYWy55WmpySxl0Mzj6e2EIUP4lmUJpa6jZUEfhBwNcTNEyfyUIcafwOKsio0BstY2MgEwWqQ5nmuj32sbXt06PASTCDOAPA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Iso-intensity contours of the adaptively smoothed X-ray emission from a 10\u00a0ks Chandra observation of MACSJ0553 overlaid on a colour-composite image created from UH2.2m observations conducted in 2011 February in the V, R and I filters. The distribution of both galaxies and intracluster gas is far from regular and relaxed. Reproduced from Mann &amp; Ebeling (2012).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083817/stx1636fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083817\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=0W6WnPKIN17hygj2x1kkoD8Psw8lzNPkeOYUGvwOKufNC-z~I3t9B2vWogQjAjUPX02xy65X-i8mslCsA~I08brP4V7qiIHHFtbUAftE2RZrhk0vkqPygkoxLsIhQM8v2p6tXHbFRSBD4g77XAPtj2cS2A5mz~h40Sj1-YO450AGMc-Klqle5Xv3q-JxP0RN6McKBQmOVVEE5Ixzov0xGlAe8mIwiQMboUgu-CdIHI-a7Z8fA8jBH97qM6Gb7~Sxk0Ett~6pB6Q9mwXGNEFy7fURzfZgG1N4INhH5dpioXyJtuHxc0xXhstsn3Ymbur6qtdes3n3N~C0YS7ZGP50mw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083817&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Iso-intensity contours of the adaptively smoothed X-ray emission from a 10\u00a0ks <em>Chandra</em> observation of MACSJ0553 overlaid on a colour-composite image created from UH2.2m observations conducted in 2011 February in the <em>V, R</em> and <em>I</em> filters. The distribution of both galaxies and intracluster gas is far from regular and relaxed.
