When converted to comoving velocities, the best-fitting Gaussian has a velocity dispersion of 1490\u00a0km\u00a0s\u22121. The redshift histograms for the eastern and western parts of the distribution (divided by the dotted line of Fig.\u00a08) are characterized by similarly high-velocity dispersions; their offset from each other is not statistically significant. The redshifts of the western and eastern BCG, as well as of the jellyfish galaxy discussed in Section\u00a06.1.2, are marked.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083875/stx1636fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083875\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=obQ3rcTe4yEU4bqGY1VnNzGxFlU2GlIKSMWSl3XDiE8GIAEGw1QY3bCOBEvilw6dbnJRqDkDLnP9bGkjJYXns7pd69DcspnLLpRb5YM2rsY3cJljk54q8kcCDX9vfqWjWEUu8RUfZgcMC1OdhzVvf3TaBfk26UjGUfjK77xJLA~k1QsCwrPsF6YCgGs1l4kgyPYxi-YJXgohigz4X8YWgRebq35nYd09ulpXhAlVH874yrF3s6Q4Jv2F9nQ7EavzF-kuG1N-5TaFzxfnS6PHoZWLuWSO7QkhYBjoyztcqmk9Fz0rbkY1yUyre7854jysDCh83nHDVkxsFil8y5NveA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083875&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Redshift distribution of cluster members. When converted to comoving velocities, the best-fitting Gaussian has a velocity dispersion of 1490\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>. The redshift histograms for the eastern and western parts of the distribution (divided by the dotted line of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>) are characterized by similarly high-velocity dispersions; their offset from each other is not statistically significant. The redshifts of the western and eastern BCG, as well as of the jellyfish galaxy discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-1-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-1-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.1.2</a>, are marked.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The two BCGs of MACSJ0553, highlighted in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, feature redshifts of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.4277 (east) and 0.4225 (west). Along our line of sight, and relative to the eastern BCG, the western BCG thus moves towards us with a velocity of 460\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>. No significant relative bulk motion is observed though when the galaxy distribution is divided into an eastern and western subset at the right ascension marked by the dotted line in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>: the centres of the respective best-fitting Gaussians are located at 0.4264 and 0.4277 (eastern and western subset, respectively) which is insignificant given the uncertainties of 0.001 in the location of the centroid of either Gaussian.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=95083877 id=\"95083877\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-1-1>6.1.1 Foreground group</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As can be gleaned from Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a> (but not from Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>), the field of MACSJ0553 also contains a likely foreground group at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.266, three members of which have spectroscopic redshifts. Although this system is irrelevant for the physics of the MACSJ0553 merger event, it is noteworthy in as much as its brightest member, highlighted on the top left of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> was mistaken for a bright cluster member by Harvey et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) (see Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec11\"></span><a href=\"#sec11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">B</a> for a discussion of the consequences of this misidentification).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=95083879 id=\"95083879\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-1-2>6.1.2 Jellyfish</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">More relevant in the context of MACSJ0553 is a different, extremely bright galaxy that is a spectroscopically confirmed cluster member. MACSJ0553\u2212JFG1, shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>, exhibits several characteristics of ongoing ram-pressure stripping, including the suggestive unilateral debris trail of star-forming regions associated with \u2018jellyfish\u2019 galaxies (e.g. Cortese et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Sun, Donahue &amp; Voit\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Owers et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Ebeling, Stephenson &amp; Edge\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; McPartland et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The location of MACSJ0553\u2212JFG1 is marked in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>; note the excellent alignment of the debris trail with the direction to the centre of the western component of MACSJ0553, 135\u00a0kpc away in projection. At a redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.4418, MACSJ0553\u2212JFG1 lies in the high-velocity tail of the redshift distribution shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> and falls towards the western BCG (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.4255) with a relative line-of-sight velocity of 3400\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>. The presence of a unilateral debris trail suggests a significant velocity component in the plane of the sky though, implying that the system's true speed must be substantially higher, thus making MACSJ0553\u2212JFG1 one of the fastest infalling galaxies known to date.</p>                        <a id=\"95083881\" scrollto-destination=\"95083881\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=ztNkGbKklZWh5ESXlh2QI92UtqfFYRWSiggmeuIz42pYEhLe6KhcFinZp5cXxN7TaAALfc~ZMHACA4U5XtHM4M1dt-ThWAf4HEdQ4H0iezz-f~yObSTCJ20PzJOKMgavLlUva6tL2yMrsMTkEmESLdDc5WJeWexyaASUA14cokoBvEMMucyivTkmR~8zU9j96M2LrEqRpqGYnSpXwBNkKDm4ABlCjBWyxypNjhAaD8Awj3QxiE6vpolpZbwC0doCmdHZOKko-eKWeGSfgdewoCeBL5DNJnrY2KR0kW1BuESIYZlMI4s3RWieW7fsiMbzV7LDUtznp16b8INXhPe-3A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A dramatic example of ram-pressure stripping by the western component of MACSJ0553. Shown at two different stretches, this 10\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010\u00a0arcsec2HST/ACS image of MACSJ0553\u2212JFG1 reveals the tell-tale debris trail and thus the direction of motion of an infalling spiral transformed into a \u2018jellyfish\u2019 galaxy. The BCG of the western component is to the upper left of this image (see Fig.\u00a06), suggesting approximately radial infall.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083881/stx1636fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083881\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=H7DI5c5EMYJwSE22IA2ybIoQ2f3fPmtvhI8LIfLX8NVnfmRzOcIfmrOixMzzxkrwvuK~xK62eP-kDkFyY~B8LCk6~ffUwCKoKwW-gbiREqqUWN6gq7oZODkN6WT7o8wLBhcinj0AZ9eUPHxPFvURaRgEV-kfZAM70P4eJ9VAyNY0dfH7FJGci16gwlMoAkfG4GUaFi2H09uOVGeXS6JSPeMq71MU9FQQFHmol-6J346CaXbhQ~By8ShFE9FF4vnGuhUjZU0Vilq8fb3R6QvSP0d5vi8ZIg45f7nwWKn02Px-egUS84Mq0jXFjWzD1Lq5jochJD702dIDxebmMvgp0Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083881&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A dramatic example of ram-pressure stripping by the western component of MACSJ0553. Shown at two different stretches, this 10\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010\u00a0arcsec<sup>2</sup><em>HST</em>/ACS image of MACSJ0553\u2212JFG1 reveals the tell-tale debris trail and thus the direction of motion of an infalling spiral transformed into a \u2018jellyfish\u2019 galaxy. The BCG of the western component is to the upper left of this image (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>), suggesting approximately radial infall.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=ztNkGbKklZWh5ESXlh2QI92UtqfFYRWSiggmeuIz42pYEhLe6KhcFinZp5cXxN7TaAALfc~ZMHACA4U5XtHM4M1dt-ThWAf4HEdQ4H0iezz-f~yObSTCJ20PzJOKMgavLlUva6tL2yMrsMTkEmESLdDc5WJeWexyaASUA14cokoBvEMMucyivTkmR~8zU9j96M2LrEqRpqGYnSpXwBNkKDm4ABlCjBWyxypNjhAaD8Awj3QxiE6vpolpZbwC0doCmdHZOKko-eKWeGSfgdewoCeBL5DNJnrY2KR0kW1BuESIYZlMI4s3RWieW7fsiMbzV7LDUtznp16b8INXhPe-3A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A dramatic example of ram-pressure stripping by the western component of MACSJ0553. Shown at two different stretches, this 10\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010\u00a0arcsec2HST/ACS image of MACSJ0553\u2212JFG1 reveals the tell-tale debris trail and thus the direction of motion of an infalling spiral transformed into a \u2018jellyfish\u2019 galaxy. The BCG of the western component is to the upper left of this image (see Fig.\u00a06), suggesting approximately radial infall.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083881/stx1636fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083881\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=H7DI5c5EMYJwSE22IA2ybIoQ2f3fPmtvhI8LIfLX8NVnfmRzOcIfmrOixMzzxkrwvuK~xK62eP-kDkFyY~B8LCk6~ffUwCKoKwW-gbiREqqUWN6gq7oZODkN6WT7o8wLBhcinj0AZ9eUPHxPFvURaRgEV-kfZAM70P4eJ9VAyNY0dfH7FJGci16gwlMoAkfG4GUaFi2H09uOVGeXS6JSPeMq71MU9FQQFHmol-6J346CaXbhQ~By8ShFE9FF4vnGuhUjZU0Vilq8fb3R6QvSP0d5vi8ZIg45f7nwWKn02Px-egUS84Mq0jXFjWzD1Lq5jochJD702dIDxebmMvgp0Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083881&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A dramatic example of ram-pressure stripping by the western component of MACSJ0553. Shown at two different stretches, this 10\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010\u00a0arcsec<sup>2</sup><em>HST</em>/ACS image of MACSJ0553\u2212JFG1 reveals the tell-tale debris trail and thus the direction of motion of an infalling spiral transformed into a \u2018jellyfish\u2019 galaxy. The BCG of the western component is to the upper left of this image (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>), suggesting approximately radial infall.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=95083882 id=\"95083882\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-2>6.2 ICM properties</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We first determine MACSJ0553\u2019s global X-ray characteristics within <em>r</em><sub>1000</sub>, the radius within which the overdensity of matter equals 1000\u00a0times the critical density.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">5</a></sup> For <em>r</em><sub>1000</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.04\u00a0Mpc (186\u00a0arcsec) the best-fitting single-temperature plasma model is described by a redshift of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z = 0.434^{+0.02}_{-0.03}$|\u2060</span>, a metal abundance of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$Z = 0.22_{-0.06}^{+0.05}$|</span> Z<sub>\u2299</sub>, an equivalent column density of neutral hydrogen of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$n_{\\rm H} = 4.3_{-0.5}^{+0.7}\\times 10^{20}$|</span>\u00a0cm<sup>\u22122</sup> and a gas temperature of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$kT = 11.5^{+0.7}_{-0.9}$|</span>\u00a0keV. Noting that the X-ray redshift is fully consistent with the more precisely determined optical redshift, we freeze <em>z</em> at 0.4270; we also freeze <em>n</em><sub>H</sub> at the Galactic value of 3.32\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>20</sup>\u00a0cm<sup>\u22122</sup> determined from 21\u00a0cm observations (Kalberla et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) and set <em>Z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.25, consistent with our best-fitting value and with the findings of Ettori et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) for the inner regions of massive, disturbed clusters at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.4. Repeating the fit, we find a global value of <em>kT</em>\u00a0=\u00a0(12.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.6)\u00a0keV. The global spectrum and the corresponding best-fitting plasma model are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"95083884\" scrollto-destination=\"95083884\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=pvtVAwGoCp-8APCpb2wVjxvB71GiRn-iRw7pkdVu3PGrlFTDw5f9gymgqV0GqXQmeBzved648YbRj8ItolhomPnmryD0yg~ktyqez~EiRojF9vxiByfEVO60aTSKWEDWs9JDdpr9CjraawKT5u4fwuhOQDJ69vGdf4sqaDSzqQYMLqL0HX2eUwXTMdvQYbWAEZalKcftbPcvSAKHKOZ~VUSReCllf39bX~59s6K8In8ZgaJuK-9Swa2zhV3UEWsTAxm0i1fsF6m8dHjbSXFlQ1qK9ojm7wfyiZ00mq0hWpxldG8C~nbnkYuuPUwTlQ7AtqLTtuzZmwV3r09JhPpCNg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"X-ray spectrum of MACSJ0553 as seen with Chandra ACIS-I, extracted with r1000. The best-fitting single-temperature plasma model is overlaid in red. The best-fitting values for the gas temperature and metal abundance are quoted in Table\u00a04.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083884/stx1636fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083884\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=ePUBFkCw-XE8px9Xar8owpFVw0ZmzDmGRMv2~vZX6J67vlxUShX1eJI~Ige5XZJMBXHbJXwgk~T9ien1VN4PhtQBbF0uHhF0c2ijVrV-xA-3NczT6Yxzp3u2bFxmRAnWC7sSU0eJ8nn3yXxodZKs~-3VctJJxJAQeiTj4jNGzHIDJQu5C3LX0P~A5kqd0~NDd4qC4crxpKCmSyS5DrXPhhNVgkH1jht3eVpXzG8aD6hsnFGNWLgfviobP8x2CKbW0iTdcZ6WhVGOfOScuPrEtl14OJauU0A92mua0OnekkF1iJImiaF3IIqO565r7g7FCyAb3HDEmkAkPDVPnvBBlw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083884&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">X-ray spectrum of MACSJ0553 as seen with <em>Chandra</em> ACIS-I, extracted with <em>r</em><sub>1000</sub>. The best-fitting single-temperature plasma model is overlaid in red. The best-fitting values for the gas temperature and metal abundance are quoted in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=pvtVAwGoCp-8APCpb2wVjxvB71GiRn-iRw7pkdVu3PGrlFTDw5f9gymgqV0GqXQmeBzved648YbRj8ItolhomPnmryD0yg~ktyqez~EiRojF9vxiByfEVO60aTSKWEDWs9JDdpr9CjraawKT5u4fwuhOQDJ69vGdf4sqaDSzqQYMLqL0HX2eUwXTMdvQYbWAEZalKcftbPcvSAKHKOZ~VUSReCllf39bX~59s6K8In8ZgaJuK-9Swa2zhV3UEWsTAxm0i1fsF6m8dHjbSXFlQ1qK9ojm7wfyiZ00mq0hWpxldG8C~nbnkYuuPUwTlQ7AtqLTtuzZmwV3r09JhPpCNg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"X-ray spectrum of MACSJ0553 as seen with Chandra ACIS-I, extracted with r1000. The best-fitting single-temperature plasma model is overlaid in red. The best-fitting values for the gas temperature and metal abundance are quoted in Table\u00a04.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083884/stx1636fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083884\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=ePUBFkCw-XE8px9Xar8owpFVw0ZmzDmGRMv2~vZX6J67vlxUShX1eJI~Ige5XZJMBXHbJXwgk~T9ien1VN4PhtQBbF0uHhF0c2ijVrV-xA-3NczT6Yxzp3u2bFxmRAnWC7sSU0eJ8nn3yXxodZKs~-3VctJJxJAQeiTj4jNGzHIDJQu5C3LX0P~A5kqd0~NDd4qC4crxpKCmSyS5DrXPhhNVgkH1jht3eVpXzG8aD6hsnFGNWLgfviobP8x2CKbW0iTdcZ6WhVGOfOScuPrEtl14OJauU0A92mua0OnekkF1iJImiaF3IIqO565r7g7FCyAb3HDEmkAkPDVPnvBBlw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083884&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">X-ray spectrum of MACSJ0553 as seen with <em>Chandra</em> ACIS-I, extracted with <em>r</em><sub>1000</sub>. The best-fitting single-temperature plasma model is overlaid in red. The best-fitting values for the gas temperature and metal abundance are quoted in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=95083885 id=\"95083885\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-2-1>6.2.1 Spatial ICM distribution</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The salient features of our target's appearance in the X-ray regime, evident in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, are as follows: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Highly elliptical large-scale emission, along a major axis aligned with the vector connecting the two BCGs.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">A pronounced X-ray peak at the location of the eastern BCG.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">No evidence of an X-ray luminous core at the location of the western BCG.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">A second X-ray peak about 200\u00a0kpc east of the eastern BCG that is not associated with any galaxy overdensity.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">A question-mark-shaped trail of bright, diffuse X-ray emission connecting, and extending beyond, the two X-ray peaks.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">A sharp drop in X-ray surface brightness to the east of the eastern X-ray peak.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We examine the area referred to in the last point above in more detail, in order to assess whether the apparent surface brightness discontinuity is consistent with a shock front or cold front. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a> (centre) shows a close-up view of the respective part of our X-ray image; the two overlaid sectors, designed to isolate the putative front, extend over a radial distance of 60\u00a0arcsec and angles of 20 and 40\u00a0deg, respectively. In both regions the extracted surface brightness profile exhibits a sudden drop at a radial distance from the eastern BCG of approximately 43\u00a0arcsec (240\u00a0kpc). The discontinuity is more pronounced (amounting to a drop by about a factor of 2) within the upper region, which contains the eastern X-ray peak, but is more significant in the larger, 40\u00a0deg wide segment (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>, top and bottom).</p>                        <a id=\"95083888\" scrollto-destination=\"95083888\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=CUcVRgDzEUYOexIKtFjZjvOGR5t~z19C1T95JfQjFmLUNQI3-NXpE6LKpQJ4CKVz5EzOTDtWFhxeBX~sYf4cNabmAmWYnPF40EWpWrNyXHDpEonVx6kZSSeAmK1ATf~DJ~-fNW5dBsIxV-Do18VqylcQcjhvXmpFSU7tLlUVUVLjUq3kr3q0PTMCbFS3SjETY-nG8GZt~GBcGgTbrhGmwD1ZJjbd5PEG9dAONSLEYFXaejuK5iqKuJzqutR7P-uWd6E2rvQ4Wt8Zn9nhJtkoVtlvRT4d~3t3W0dvwVZHG7XrRAGDYKpSSksdQw0~3yIz3jN6zguwO3xNDf5PBP0M9g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Centre: Close-up view of the X-ray emission from MACSJ0553 around the eastern surface brightness discontinuity. Top: Surface brightness profile for the upper pie segment, outlined by the dashed yellow line in the central panel; shown on the x-axis is the radial distance from the brightest X-ray peak that coincides with the eastern BCG in MACSJ0553. The best-fitting power-law description of the emission in the cluster outskirts is shown in red. Bottom: As top panel, but showing the data extracted from the wider pie segment, outlined in blue in the central panel.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083888/stx1636fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083888\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=FD38kk4nXkx~MfCX5j29Sc4j~-McY3R6W67u7wrNMqOPZLrxnEKCwTBiYdDuJ4T7iJ6mqqSta9QbQosSNnu4zkthbezFVK8X0PG5wAGZ90lj-kmGX005s9K7aTqBZFsNdqMLisuoNS0yl48yqWn9C0aYWZItPk7gPnD58q3r6ro1L6VgBDuSVmXlQe5~Qv-7hijisPIkvy0AaGw94GOwCfczjEYJ1vB3QXEiYte2Es5JpQSlkLlz7hWLnZXaDW3yFVxgx9mdyriLq4cjRHfJnT7jKymOTKIrl3Cd1pEY-BluA4dNqbkGTv5Y2GSD1wbkiZMJw7jDPdzcGSw9PFou1w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083888&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Centre: Close-up view of the X-ray emission from MACSJ0553 around the eastern surface brightness discontinuity. The previously mentioned point source is visible in the upper left corner. Top: Surface brightness profile for the upper pie segment, outlined by the dashed yellow line in the central panel; shown on the <em>x</em>-axis is the radial distance from the brightest X-ray peak that coincides with the eastern BCG in MACSJ0553. The best-fitting power-law description of the emission in the cluster outskirts is shown in red. Bottom: As top panel, but showing the data extracted from the wider pie segment, outlined in blue in the central panel.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Motivated by the mentioned complete absence of an X-ray luminous core at the location of the western BCG, we also attempt to quantify the difference in gas density of the two cluster components, following the procedure described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.4</a>. After elimination of the far-eastern X-ray peak adjacent to the surface-brightness discontinuity discussed above, the remaining emission can be modelled as the superposition of two \u03b2 models. Both components show no significant ellipticity and are aligned with the respective BCG to within about 8 and 12\u00a0arcsec (50 and 70\u00a0kpc for the eastern and western component, respectively), the offsets being mainly towards the south while insignificant within the errors in the east\u2013west direction. We show the resulting cumulative gas mass profiles in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a>. As expected from even cursory inspection of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, the western component of MACSJ0553 contains significantly less intracluster gas than the eastern one.</p>                        <a id=\"95083890\" scrollto-destination=\"95083890\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=GwSPzw3326ryWab08oy4ozj-KktF3iltGsWKnhloVDeAIv8JQXgUADYixjwWuk98YIbDoyxIiORTQ5SALjd5Z0kSAkC1-rcWCTwArjgYA8sXCBGlp6KjE5IukvBV0FqC~xZW5cRi1NripF7ruxHnH8CGRqdrPbEpH-wwcX4k2gT~NJcP-frKmcaprHUaW0gqbsr-YrrU30AdY9HaD8QdILY1ge-xHRchgvqXF3Shrw4OdcMQGbdhbnB52LN1p2T7sIr2EBvh8Sz9WKBijV~fWU6kCw-OIfaTk4TcRJIM58IazIO-kovvbiLZUvwvW7~eWTv8NSZB6F0SrX292pPy0A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cumulative profiles of the gas mass of the two cluster components based on \u03b2 models. The width of each profile represents the systematic uncertainties introduced by our inability to constrain the parameters characterizing the steepening of the emission at large radii and reflect the range of results obtained for all combinations of rs\u00a0=\u00a01000,\u20091500\u00a0kpc and \u03b5\u00a0=\u00a02, 3 (see text for details).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig13.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083890/stx1636fig13.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig13.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083890\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=NgCvmH2gFxn7EGEDOQz8vOWbWDKk4DWsmcg0ejJNtxRhXXFqAsArxAS-ZXepNMsyRAWxVlRpnalRNdZp2oiEH9F3q4svQiQZDugLtQVwaG6cA3qJdoqFH~VMJgcx6DgSfv7w9MMRfL5wLxLKJCcqbFbV2z-LSqpkwPhQ8zbYWLkLaxPvvIWQjik4msWVrss3hg~1HbxOrQ41xhI2REIkeRDRC5Rb-ELIrgNaS29PPXF5jxcjbzHN3xIrPWfvagN4lDzwXpXV6O17JmnwMFsaScbJXLSVj11ipBy5ZxTdmCJ1rNg4u0KYmtohLuBuP-fd3QRpO9bwmmK9TTGEYX-RfQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083890&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig13.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cumulative profiles of the gas mass of the two cluster components based on \u03b2 models. The width of each profile represents the systematic uncertainties introduced by our inability to constrain the parameters characterizing the steepening of the emission at large radii and reflect the range of results obtained for all combinations of <em>r</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01000,\u20091500\u00a0kpc and \u03b5\u00a0=\u00a02, 3 (see text for details).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=GwSPzw3326ryWab08oy4ozj-KktF3iltGsWKnhloVDeAIv8JQXgUADYixjwWuk98YIbDoyxIiORTQ5SALjd5Z0kSAkC1-rcWCTwArjgYA8sXCBGlp6KjE5IukvBV0FqC~xZW5cRi1NripF7ruxHnH8CGRqdrPbEpH-wwcX4k2gT~NJcP-frKmcaprHUaW0gqbsr-YrrU30AdY9HaD8QdILY1ge-xHRchgvqXF3Shrw4OdcMQGbdhbnB52LN1p2T7sIr2EBvh8Sz9WKBijV~fWU6kCw-OIfaTk4TcRJIM58IazIO-kovvbiLZUvwvW7~eWTv8NSZB6F0SrX292pPy0A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cumulative profiles of the gas mass of the two cluster components based on \u03b2 models. The width of each profile represents the systematic uncertainties introduced by our inability to constrain the parameters characterizing the steepening of the emission at large radii and reflect the range of results obtained for all combinations of <em>r</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01000,\u20091500\u00a0kpc and \u03b5\u00a0=\u00a02, 3 (see text for details).</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=95083891 id=\"95083891\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-2-2>6.2.2 ICM temperature map</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Following the approach taken by Ma, Ebeling &amp; Barrett (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), we start our exploration of ICM temperature variations in MACSJ0553 using <span class=\"small-caps\">contbin</span> tessellations for modest SNR values of 15, 20, and 25. Improving upon the strategy of Ma and co-workers, we suppress the geometric noise present in any individual realization by creating a geometrically averaged \u2018temperature trend\u2019 map as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.3</a>. We then median average the trend maps for our three SNR values (15, 20 and 25) to arrive at the map shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"95083893\" scrollto-destination=\"95083893\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig14\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 14.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig14.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=QoPDlKuwni75J1u-9AHHq5w-X1QQ3cBeMh-ifO9NL6DDmjBTd6KnTgxkwAEO24rnN5VkVTKUFYQ6LApym43QcJfU6GOz0mybw5hcteNqlet7aElHzorb81etSypHFMhaR-WNOrqI3b~qeXss9cesjiAIkxVI8i~E-Vh8-iqG~vQkfB6i-nBWUH5CLeqdRioc2RPCNGOdv2alM59rLlfWE~D8LPEGTeibNbd6o22O~qDWQ2VOOVAwfyHYIV-5rD0qjKyh8ie4~KMCMnb2JanV785IhWmcfqODsTkbpgb13S5r3txb3fqrKHydZ-lDpAiV17tBUN98XNizBMd09GQsyQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"ICM temperature trends within MACSJ0553, obtained by median-averaging temperature trend maps for signal-to-noise values of 15, 20 and 25 (see Section\u00a04.3). Delineated in white are the regions defined by us to capture the apparent temperature variations. As in Fig.\u00a03, the green lines delineate the ACIS-I chip gaps and the green crosses mark the location of the two BCGS.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig14.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083893/stx1636fig14.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig14.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083893\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig14.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=HgsspzBfnNd~7g7nzftonjI2UbhWyUdGJvtUBWB2aEYffkVDMJFc28Ue5DzJCW~Dfa~iOwBe7koydWmmwHxhIe7~H5huUfujTxM35DIZLpHFIDu4vS0LYx1qFiiE1gQFDCeloIWPiJ75GQp16dclyMy6s4wpJjoMgLQ9fhvsWWA42G-zD6O8yP1jWCat0noNpsTMPzrUPoChWZ2freUW-gcke6TgPNDo1GsjzxI~FyWmhBamlcSToqQ6F4fCxgyGQEVWXuA~pVfVjiKXZ3VXkrfTlfjF69MVoMPbjfj7MvYXcCMeKcUNw3bqdIzwT1-niDqTETXHD9cg7EBuZMIyzw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083893&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig14.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">ICM temperature trends within MACSJ0553, obtained by median-averaging temperature trend maps for signal-to-noise values of 15, 20 and 25 (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.3</a>). Delineated in white are the regions defined by us to capture the apparent temperature variations. As in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, the green lines delineate the ACIS-I chip gaps and the green crosses mark the location of the two BCGS.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig14\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 14.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig14.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=QoPDlKuwni75J1u-9AHHq5w-X1QQ3cBeMh-ifO9NL6DDmjBTd6KnTgxkwAEO24rnN5VkVTKUFYQ6LApym43QcJfU6GOz0mybw5hcteNqlet7aElHzorb81etSypHFMhaR-WNOrqI3b~qeXss9cesjiAIkxVI8i~E-Vh8-iqG~vQkfB6i-nBWUH5CLeqdRioc2RPCNGOdv2alM59rLlfWE~D8LPEGTeibNbd6o22O~qDWQ2VOOVAwfyHYIV-5rD0qjKyh8ie4~KMCMnb2JanV785IhWmcfqODsTkbpgb13S5r3txb3fqrKHydZ-lDpAiV17tBUN98XNizBMd09GQsyQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"ICM temperature trends within MACSJ0553, obtained by median-averaging temperature trend maps for signal-to-noise values of 15, 20 and 25 (see Section\u00a04.3). Delineated in white are the regions defined by us to capture the apparent temperature variations. As in Fig.\u00a03, the green lines delineate the ACIS-I chip gaps and the green crosses mark the location of the two BCGS.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig14.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083893/stx1636fig14.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig14.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083893\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig14.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=HgsspzBfnNd~7g7nzftonjI2UbhWyUdGJvtUBWB2aEYffkVDMJFc28Ue5DzJCW~Dfa~iOwBe7koydWmmwHxhIe7~H5huUfujTxM35DIZLpHFIDu4vS0LYx1qFiiE1gQFDCeloIWPiJ75GQp16dclyMy6s4wpJjoMgLQ9fhvsWWA42G-zD6O8yP1jWCat0noNpsTMPzrUPoChWZ2freUW-gcke6TgPNDo1GsjzxI~FyWmhBamlcSToqQ6F4fCxgyGQEVWXuA~pVfVjiKXZ3VXkrfTlfjF69MVoMPbjfj7MvYXcCMeKcUNw3bqdIzwT1-niDqTETXHD9cg7EBuZMIyzw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083893&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig14.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">ICM temperature trends within MACSJ0553, obtained by median-averaging temperature trend maps for signal-to-noise values of 15, 20 and 25 (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.3</a>). Delineated in white are the regions defined by us to capture the apparent temperature variations. As in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, the green lines delineate the ACIS-I chip gaps and the green crosses mark the location of the two BCGS.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Inspection of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a> reveals several noteworthy features: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">MACSJ0553 contains one of the hottest ICM observed so far in a galaxy cluster, with ambient temperatures of about 10\u00a0keV and extended regions within which the gas temperature is effectively too high to be meaningfully constrained with <em>Chandra</em> (<em>kT</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a018\u00a0keV).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The location of both X-ray peaks coincides with regions containing the coolest gas in the entire cluster (<em>kT</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a08\u00a0keV).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Only one of the two X-ray peaks (the western one) aligns with an overdensity of galaxies; it is surrounded by much hotter gas that extends to a radius of 100\u2013200\u00a0kpc from the cluster core.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Although no X-ray peak is observed in this region, the ICM at the location of the eastern subcluster (marked by a very prominent BCG) appears to be much hotter than the ambient gas.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">An arc of extremely hot gas (<em>kT</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a020\u00a0keV), extending over some 400\u00a0kpc, follows the X-ray surface brightness contours at the eastern end of the cluster, and a similar, but much broader arc of exceptionally hot gas is seen in the far west; both of these features fall into regions of relatively low X-ray surface brightness.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Anchored by another region of very hot gas in the south, a tentative bridge of heated ICM connects the two arcs.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since the temperature trend maps used so far are all derived from measurements performed within regions of modest SNR, we now define larger, physically motivated areas designed to isolate the mentioned features, as outlined in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a>. The resulting, coarse temperature map for MACSJ0553 is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a>; results from the spectral fits are summarized numerically and graphically in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> and Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig16\" data-open=\"fig16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">16</a>, respectively.</p>                        <a id=\"95083896\" scrollto-destination=\"95083896\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig15\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 15.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig15.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=JKT8V4jjdzvynxOXUE3x4E6SH8~TKjcGlRvf88aRkLg2VuW97NE15F~khDvzDb5h3y~vU7LBLDb-us8RHY6vVwyHPR0XyktAAdqkggDWwxzw-9b3EPkAeJ9wb~EeeZ-oS47jKXn2iPtf-5vuHgeg~aSP5ZFx7AWrcS0AeMPpIWNi4CNDskjfSURbwgotL7DaisUtuDEHWyMS7zRb60wXSs8fE-3MN9W5mfEdOKyM2~h4kgEp-TaaKuc70bBba0fG2ZJldP98L7ChU4cVwq~Lee-IzUkNdZRw-I-tgGlqh-NjHum0b3h4XIqirC26MWZzPcsJav9PW9WQA4pcj8TRQQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"ICM temperatures map based on the regions shown in Fig.\u00a014. Regions are numbered as in Fig.\u00a016. For clarity, we do not label the oval regions associated with the two X-ray peaks and marked with asterisks in Table\u00a05.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig15.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083896/stx1636fig15.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig15.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083896\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig15.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=x5PVLMhI299yvmN0h8hhD8YIorj3simPuHivs4WsSnt8yTeHhxEe4SqlD3ukOqcqGYFX74MMuWXSyLWLE3tR3Bp8RG4gbXdJcl7iwttvR3x7c3hbU8qqbzvRmnfF~AxKKdIFbOAu7abp-xl06AFm-utiYnc-pwG6oiDcB2UxYhaTXE93v0FAXjjBVp4~O4ZaM-35szpHcqv~UekQB~Ba~3yw9ozVwm0KzY4jeUT8fW1RrrG3KvWfjGi1WmFVlXYxVLrQWRp-EodoB6JlPZc32V4-y~uJOIVjzh260KWbAClrb34FCMEzboX1KRQwBF6l3fg1rghGQtH1~FCNM8FEvA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083896&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig15.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">ICM temperatures map based on the regions shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a>. The dual data points for regions 1 and 2 refer to the circular and oval versions.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig16.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083897/stx1636fig16.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig16.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083897\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig16.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=XxdTs73t6KndM1-TLhQhgXMM8Dem6mnobX7ZJO4cAydccIyD14is84rvHX1ytd~Qt3g8PlKtc0mWKAFtaNSbXFXyjSu~k1GtEJhC54F4QNnsxUWJHd20ylscTIodqKX9EOe2BWdQEj~f-kGAZI1y0~ZSkBuMMV-6KhXNtsUxY3KP7hjy84j0w0zh~0qwJhFhllkP~rEb8otpkfyK-w40aPX-FVFSNrMWc4I0fOmG48CnVVdr~W587t5l6m50tRL0xnDnjfie0rragpVQkQsrWZNss6l03ww0P0IVN6Avtpq8bu4RK0E4DSxyt7qqBDfN-ZlmuPHcIoPJV~2Ng7dFJA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083897&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig16.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">ICM temperatures measured within the regions shown in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a>, in rank order. Regions can be matched by number with those shown in our coarse temperature map (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a>); numerical results are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. The dual data points for regions 1 and 2 refer to the circular and oval versions.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig16\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 16.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig16.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=LbZRoXTndRtKd~hsXJnLTS~B2LWSuTJqG9Gp3qSEHYwgoJ0GaEHOyWjsq6QdwS1Waq7bpU0ZWMG1o9s1LpGvcqZBui8f8p-vKQlg6jj1KPCYkNeWqdulk5XWQ8-c11oM8oFqbeLfT~legkuhyXbTGUkjaPa3jTBAYOAmnT8VyGN2yvPW--p87s7n5IA4EXGCoeH-I7q2qUVzWKXop4QggL22DjtXUsSpioKypVnS6QG9yOiofeQRFMia30QsVc1zJJbppiXPQ6SrqwAzic8L2u7zr4TZqbebjGFEv6v270ebNLCjzzu~wio4M~TwylhwrLzbi7USCJ3odp0CdU3U9w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"ICM temperatures measured within the regions shown in Figs\u00a014 and\u00a015, in rank order. The dual data points for regions 1 and 2 refer to the circular and oval versions.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig16.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083897/stx1636fig16.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig16.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083897\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig16.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=XxdTs73t6KndM1-TLhQhgXMM8Dem6mnobX7ZJO4cAydccIyD14is84rvHX1ytd~Qt3g8PlKtc0mWKAFtaNSbXFXyjSu~k1GtEJhC54F4QNnsxUWJHd20ylscTIodqKX9EOe2BWdQEj~f-kGAZI1y0~ZSkBuMMV-6KhXNtsUxY3KP7hjy84j0w0zh~0qwJhFhllkP~rEb8otpkfyK-w40aPX-FVFSNrMWc4I0fOmG48CnVVdr~W587t5l6m50tRL0xnDnjfie0rragpVQkQsrWZNss6l03ww0P0IVN6Avtpq8bu4RK0E4DSxyt7qqBDfN-ZlmuPHcIoPJV~2Ng7dFJA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083897&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig16.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">ICM temperatures measured within the regions shown in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a>, in rank order. style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>kT</em> (keV)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>SNR<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$7.4_{-1.5}^{+2.4}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>22.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>1*\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$7.8_{-1.2}^{+1.9}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>32.4\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$9.5_{-2.7}^{+6.2}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>19.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2*\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$9.5_{-2.1}^{+3.8}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>26.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>3\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$10.2_{-0.9}^{+1.1}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>79.4\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>4\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$11.8_{-1.1}^{+1.1}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>91.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>5\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$12.7_{-1.3}^{+1.5}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>79.3\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>6\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$15.8_{-2.2}^{+2.7}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>65.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>7\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$17.9_{-4.0}^{+7.5}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>36.3\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>8\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$20.3_{-7.6}^{+19.3}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>28.5\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/95083898\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Consistent with the temperature trends discussed above, the coolest gas is found in the vicinity of the eastern X-ray peak; similar temperatures are measured near the western X-ray peak (i.e. the core of the western cluster), and in the outskirts of MACSJ0553. Significantly hotter gas is observed in the eastern and western arcs, but also around the western BCG, where the X-ray surface brightness remains perfectly flat. The sharp increase in temperature of approximately a factor of 2 between regions 1 and 6 coincides with the surface-brightness drop by about the same factor discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.2.1</a> and shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>. As a result, the ICM is in approximate pressure equilibrium across this feature, suggesting that it is a cold front (Markevitch &amp; Vikhlinin\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Judging from the results of our spectral fits, the ICM in the western region 8 is extremely hot and features temperatures around or above 20\u00a0keV that are too high to be meaningfully constrained with <em>Chandra</em>. In addition, the reduced \u03c7<sup>2</sup> values for the four largest regions (#3, 4, 6 and 8) all exceed unity, suggesting that our model represents an imperfect description of the data. Indeed, the stark temperature differences measured in MACSJ0553 are most likely indicative of multiphase gas seen in projection. However, attempts to fit two-temperature models fail to yield improved fits at the current photon statistics.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=95083901 id=\"95083901\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-3>6.3 Mass distribution: single, binary or triple?</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We tested several assumptions for the large-scale mass components, where we describe the mass distribution as the sum of elliptical mass haloes. The large east\u2013west spread of all multiple systems requires a highly elliptical global mass distribution which is not well modelled by a single smooth mass component. Instead, our baseline model uses two cluster-scale elliptical potentials centred in the vicinity of each of the two BCGs. We use a Gaussian prior for this central location with \u03c3\u00a0=\u00a03\u2009arcsec to allow small offsets between the smooth mass distribution and the BCG centre. Such a model reproduces well all multiple systems, with a combined root-mean-square angular offset (rms) of 0.79\u00a0arcsec.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The puzzling presence of a concentration of highly X-ray luminous but relatively cool gas at the eastern edge of MACSJ0553 (see e.g. Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a>), in a region that contains hardly any cluster galaxies, prompts us to explore whether our strong-lensing model demands, or at least permits, a third mass component near the location of this eastern-most X-ray peak. We find that the addition of a third smooth mass component, either at the location of said X-ray peak, or in the vicinity of an apparent loose group of cluster members even farther east, fails to attributing significant mass to such a third large-scale halo and also yields no significant improvement of the combined rms. Having also confirmed that our use of Gaussian redshifts priors based on the photometric redshifts instead of a flat redshift prior does not alter the best-fitting parameters, we conclude that our extensive lensing constraints are best met by a model consisting of two almost equally massive components.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The resulting best-fitting values for the two-component model are reported in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>; the corresponding model predictions for the redshifts of all multiple-image families without spectroscopic redshifts are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"95083905\" scrollto-destination=\"95083905\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl6\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl6\" data-id=\"tbl6\"><span class=\"label\">Table 6.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Parameters of our best-fitting model for the total mass distribution of MACSJ0553. Component DM1 and DM2 describe the eastern and western cluster component, respectively. Angular offsets of the centre of each component (second and third column) are measured relative to the position of the eastern BCG.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Potential<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394\u03b1<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394\u03b4<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>e</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n Component DM1 and DM2 describe the eastern and western cluster component, respectively. class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/95083905\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;             js-p-fig-section\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig17\" data-open=\"fig17\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">17</a> overlays contours of the X-ray surface brightness distribution from Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, as well as contours of the projected mass surface density from our strong-lensing model, on to the <em>HST</em> image of MACSJ0553 and illustrates three key insights regarding the distribution of dark and luminous matter in MACSJ0553: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">All strong-lensing constraints can be satisfied with a model consisting of two components, the centres of which are well aligned with the two BCGs of MACSJ0553.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mass distribution of both components is highly elliptical.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">While the centre of the eastern mass component coincides with the western X-ray peak, we have an orphaned X-ray peak to its east (no associated mass or galaxy concentration) and no associated X-ray peak within over 600\u00a0kpc of the western component.</p></li></ul><span id=\"fig17\"></span><div data-id=\"fig17\" class=\"fig fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 17.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" Note the excellent alignment of both components of our mass model with the two BCGs, and the pronounced ellipticity of both mass concentrations.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig17.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083906/stx1636fig17.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig17.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083906\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig17.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=bLqrKVIUjFId8MtXJwIjWnDUEgfWLR8M3jJAGN8X-K-xS3qFPBjLuMJ1diVyxbHaMd9i4yBu7W7b0l9D1rKazXqAQ~O8TUdkzsq2S4YoPPcuv0NiUNAxmyIURwj0mwaX28Qt5TNGzIe9bIL0s57GaJ0-nnhbS9MyEiA2eApbljoVZo~2Tv4CWifB3lA-gAos0QwIcsN~Iv~GPSec7EdckUqPga0oUHzRca3hr6yo0udeRpqe8PAsMxTnCdYbmZHdkq6NNVukfnyYSQ2KVZ0sDzmSa6~9MTkV~MJZE9S45RvzgvI0nN3CP6JSmp20zdXq9vCwz38LaPqZnqvJKjfOCA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083906&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig17.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Projected surface mass density contours (grey) from our strong-lensing reconstruction overlaid on the <em>HST</em> colour image of MACSJ0553. Red contours show the adaptively smoothed X-ray emission from Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. Note the excellent alignment of both components of our mass model with the two BCGs, and the pronounced ellipticity of both mass concentrations.</p></div></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=95083907 id=\"95083907\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-3-1>6.3.1 Gas mass fraction</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Having established that MACSJ0553 consists of no more than two large-scale mass concentrations, centred upon the two BCGs, we can use the fact that the associated ICM distributions are also reasonably well aligned with the BCGs to constrain the gas fraction of both components by dividing the profiles shown in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig18\" data-open=\"fig18\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">18</a>. The result is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig19\" data-open=\"fig19\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">19</a>. We find the gas fraction of the eastern component of MACSJ0553 to converge towards the universal value of 0.11 (Allen et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Ettori et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), whereas the western subcluster's much more steeply declining radial X-ray surface brightness profile results in a gas mass fraction that, while not extremely low, drops significantly below that of its eastern neighbour. This difference may still not be noteworthy though, given that the gas mass fraction correlates with cluster mass. To account for this dependence, we compare our findings with the compilation of literature values presented in Dvorkin &amp; Rephaeli (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). As shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig20\" data-open=\"fig20\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">20</a>, the western component of MACSJ0553 exhibits one of the lowest gas mass fractions measured for clusters in this mass range.</p>                        <a id=\"95083909\" scrollto-destination=\"95083909\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig18\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 18.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig18.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=Szh2kdmLeZ1XTkXqCaJg8zd5L7k7al-OulpT7Dk0wa7xVNyjDwq6BYR89tfLsOHqpcA1yXYnbrBUqJl2BcRXMrWDj1grdw~6ae2ByI2wL~dSQ2zQ7jQSz-5AKrpviHeTLoGbcc3U0iuC-u4YWAB4-Cjnt-hy~-HzlE4eoKOOWXsHpVujOYAR7ivlZSyVxZStIsZPRP4QfkQzA2acL1~z9XBmOvxZ5LvNSK9YURwx6vROSMnc9b80EKpOvP6x5dqA-F7S3soVh7x~kNj~uixK4gO71n0t88iGfM90saLuMkEGRndiHt9QSAtSCcnseFan79iEos9tFgJJ6zkcc9LkwQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cumulative profile of the total gravitational mass of both cluster components based on our strong-lensing model of MACSJ0553. The red and blue lines show the mass profiles for the eastern and western component, integrated from the location of the respective BCG; the total mass profile, which adopts the position of the eastern BCG as its centre, is shown in black.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig18.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/95083909/stx1636fig18.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig18.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"95083909\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/stx1636fig18.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&Signature=WEJ1kV6UJw1eRtpJ4npntPuaBrdTXLPg~alVHxhESvSzAwWA-2h8q09NJ0AG5Hd4nUxSrgkSmh4gR~CPOMbPNMl68PcdW7Gp09xkqaiSo8PZa5BQzYfgbphVZ9xP2h2oHcuHQpjdPMfzWZd~TWP6Yl19Jha5FUbIXsWzoseHyf8e~Iq99RuEUZv6TPSQTad99~E3FXaTPNEWRr-DgxMSmj-zUPl4GGvuQK2-Sza654NX0JudUE0HoB6ogw15HgC6PZ2rp4SLO0u7oyRjHFgAkj9xJl4GlZwR1pQf8ywMZoO4wmuQLU26adBHgsYsl1d49lSQQRuOvoZgALVYMaMuww__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=95083909&ar=3899126&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1636fig18.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cumulative profile of the total gravitational mass of both cluster components based on our strong-lensing model of MACSJ0553. The red and blue lines show the mass profiles for the eastern and western component, integrated from the location of the respective BCG; the total mass profile, which adopts the position of the eastern BCG as its centre, is shown in black.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig18\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 18.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/471/3/10.1093_mnras_stx1636/2/m_stx1636fig18.jpeg?Expires=1639263328&amp;Signature=Szh2kdmLeZ1XTkXqCaJg8zd5L7k7al-OulpT7Dk0wa7xVNyjDwq6BYR89tfLsOHqpcA1yXYnbrBUqJl2BcRXMrWDj1grdw~6ae2ByI2wL~dSQ2zQ7jQSz-5AKrpviHeTLoGbcc3U0iuC-u4YWAB4-Cjnt-hy~-HzlE4eoKOOWXsHpVujOYAR7ivlZSyVxZStIsZPRP4QfkQzA2acL1~z9XBmOvxZ5LvNSK9YURwx6vROSMnc9b80EKpOvP6x5dqA-F7S3soVh7x~kNj~uixK4gO71n0t88iGfM90saLuMkEGRndiHt9QSAtSCcnseFan79iEos9tFgJJ6zkcc9LkwQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cumulative profile of the total gravitational mass of both cluster components based on our strong-lensing model of MACSJ0553.
